Tonight, we went to Pi for the first time and on our rating system, this place deserves a 4.75: excellent overall, with a few very minor complaints.  Pi has great service--warm, friendly staff who know their products and can make recommendations without being pushy.  The house-made pretzel with Sierra Nevada mustard was delicious, though slightly over-baked, and the mixed green salad was very nice and not drowned in dressing, which I appreciate.  Their beer selection is unique and varied, plus the tasting glasses are adorable little beer steins, just enough for two swallows, which is perfect.

And the pizza itself--well, it was very good.  While I'm a fan of a more sauce-driven pie (a la Little Star), I recognize that Pi is doing something different and they're doing it well.  The spicy peppers and olives was a great combo, and the small was a perfect size for two people (6 slices).  We watched another couple receive their large and balk at the giant pie in front of them.

All in all, Pi deserves a round of applause for the ambiance of the place, the great service, the soundtrack, and the food.  I highly recommend it as a Pizza Destination.  Coming from us, that's saying something.
author: Ciara W.

description: I really love this bar; its cozy, its clever, the beer and the pizza never disappoint! Bartenders are friendly and the beer selection is pretty damn good (check out the unique Belgiums in the cooler). They always have a great selection of entirely local beers including unique brews i.e. you won't get bored with only Lagunitas IPA and Anchor Steam as craft options (as great as they are they are too common). They also make some amazing pizza exactly the way I like it with thin crust and the perfect ratio of cheese to sauce NY style. For the light snacker I would recommend the homemade soft pretzel with Sierra Nevada mustard, only $1.50. Only issue with Pi Bar is that a lot of people dine here like a restaurant with big parties and kids. Thats OK but for me its more so a bar than restaurant.
author: Cori W.

description:
In short, Pi bar has the following things to truly recommend it:

Great beer selection, with tons of stuff in bottle, and a nice selection on tap.
Polenta fries (served with marinara sauce) - totally unusual, but fun and certainly tasty.
Warm spinach salad with house-made sausage, toybox tomatoes, and feta.  Really, really f'ing good.  The sausage (ground into little bits, not large chunks or slices) has a fascinating smokiness to it which really enhances the salad.  I can't believe I'm saying this, but this is even better than bacon bits on salad.

Those were the best.
The meatball sandwich was also good - the fresh basil leaves were a nice touch, and the meatballs were tender and flavorful.  It would have been nice if it had a bit more sauce, but was a tasty sandwich that I'd be happy to get again; it just wasn't quite as spectacular as the 2 items above.

The meh:
Pizza slice - the source slice (which they add toppings to and toss back in the oven to reheat) had clearly been sitting out for a while.  This was probably because we were there before they switch over to slices only (11pm) on an off-night, so there weren't many people eating slices.  This means your slices are going to be sitting around for a while.
So if you're into slices, I'd recommend going when it's a more crowded & popular time for slice-consuming to get fresher.

I have yet to try the fresh pizza, so can't comment on that.

They do have coat hooks under the bar, which is nice.  Also, I was enjoying the 70s rock soundtrack.
author: Don H.

description:
Beer selection is good but very pricy and no happy hour.  In addition, the multitudes of  kids make it way too loud for my taste, but my friends with kids like it for that same reason, of course!  

For a better beer selection at much better prices, head over to Rosamunde at 24th and Mission.  I should also mention that the bartenders aren't very nice - they tend to ignore the customers in order to converse amongst themselves.  The one with long hair typically in braids is the worst offender.
author: Heather F.

description:
This review is really three and a half stars.  I felt I couldn't give four, but it is better than three.

   First of all, fantastic beer selection, as everyone else has noticed.  I was there around the time of the 30th anniversary of Sierra Nevada Brewing, and they had some fantastic specialty beers.  I had the "Brewer's Reserve", which is a delightful blend of their Bigfoot Barley Wine and the Celebration Ale.  Yum!

   I ordered a simple salad, the anchovy side, and a slice.  What  amazed me was how fast they turned to order around... within about 5 minutes I had everything.  

  Thus the -.5 stars.  No one wants everything at once.  I expected a lesiurely snack on some anchovies (quite good), a bite of salad or two (a bit heavily dressed and too acidic, but fresh and still pretty good), and then finish up with my slice (basalmic onion, sausage, kalamata olive, good crust) over a second beer.  

  But, instead, everything was piled up in front of me at the same time.  I felt rushed, and the place wasn't that busy.  

  The place is clean, the waitstaff is nice, the beer is good and the food not bad.  3.5 stars in my book.
author: Bad Y.

description:
I'm changing my rating from 2-stars to 3, because I actually go here fairly often for their great beer selection.  I don't feel right frequenting an establishment that I've only rated 2-stars.

However, their Pizza is to be avoided.  I've tried it on 3 separate occasions, and each time it was dry, tasteless, and cardboard-ish.  Definitely not worth what they charge for it.
author: Ross G.

description: I mean, this place is dirt cheap and huge....also they have Delirium on tap. Brilliant. I've never crowded and is super easy going, lots of space to sit and tastes similar to pizza I'd find in NYC. Service is lags a little but hey, it's a bar...who cares.
author: Meredith M.

description:
I'm not sure why, but Pi Bar makes me feel all romantical.  It must be all the dark wood and dark beers and mirrors and melting cheese smell.  I had a great date here with my BF when we came in for the 3:14-6:28 HH special: $6 for thin crust pizza and a strong beer on tap which was just our style.  I liked this place too because I don't think it necessarily has a Mission feel- it's like a Nor Cal/So Cal/ Mission/North Beach/PB/OB type of joint.

We sat at the bar and chopped it up with the nice bartender who gave us our space but came back when we needed more pizza or a refill. Pizza comes standard cheese slice and you order toppings for more $.  My BF got the pepperoni and it was overflowing.  I got olives and it came with about 4 halves of green olives.  Interesting, no?  I think it all depends on how generous the pizza guy is feeling in the back.
author: Holly B.

description:
First, the non-pizza parts. There are a fair number of draft beers offered, and our waitress was very friendly and patient. The appetizers are oddly expensive and not bad, but not worth it. The fried mozzarella was $10 for maybe 8 pretty small cheese nuggets fried, sitting in red sauce. They were fine but nothing special. Similarly, the garlic pinwheels just seemed to be bread twirled and garlicked up. At 3 for $5 (and maybe slightly larger than a silver dollar), they weren't worth it either. The rainbow cookie was surprisingly better and quite decadent.  Our waitress cut the $4 dessert (more cake- than cookie-like) into 6 pieces, which worked pretty well for everyone.

Now, the pizza. I will say up front that, while I like all types of pizza, New York style is definitely my least favorite, so I'm not a connoisseur. Having said that, the cheese was not good quality, there was really almost no sauce, and the crust was not bad, but not too distinctive, and it was a bit burned. Upon request we were given parmesan cheese, and a little dish of oregano was brought with the pizza. Both helped, but I'd like the pizza to be able to stand by itself. The place had a nice overall vibe, but I wouldn't have the pizza (or appetizers) again.
author: Lisa K.

description:
I love pizza and good beer, and this place is near my house, so I thought it woul dbe a good place for an after-work dinner with friends.

GOOD: the beer selection.  They have a ton of delicious beers, both on tap and in bottles, with a big old beer encyclopedia to help you choose.

MEDIOCRE: the food.  It's fine, but all pretty bland.  We had the polenta fries, the caesar salad, the fried fresh mozzarella and the "death by mushroom" pizza (which was just a regular cheese pizza with tiny bits of mushroom hidden under the cheese).  Everything was fresh but pretty bland.  I don't know that I'd eat here again unless I came for drinks and was too lazy to go anywhere else.  The service was also pretty middling.  It took a pretty long time to order drinks at the bar, despite the place being pretty empty, and though the waitress didn't rush us (we sat at our table for four hours), she assured my friend that her order did not contain the ingredient that she is allergic too, and then told her that on second thought, it actually might, after she had already brought it to the table.

Verdict: come for great beer.  Don't bother with anything else.
author: Lauren F.

description:
Great concept and for the most part executed pretty well. The polenta fries were unique and tasty and it seems like they have a good beer menu. The pizza leaves a bit to be desired, it's New York style so it's thin but it's also incredibly greasy. The waitress was incredibly attentive and nice, great place to just hang out and watch the neighborhood out the window.

Honestly, I'm giving Pi Bar an extra star simply because being here led to the discovery of Anthony's cookies across the street. OMG.
author: Christine K.

description: cute place. loved the death by mushroom pizza sauce with caramelized onions and garlic toppings. would definitely go again. nice thing about it too is the neighborhood was easy enough to find parking in and they have bike racks. both uncommon.
author: V B.

description:
Somebody out there likes me.

Beer geek hangout spot with excellent pizza?

Maybe I did something right somewhere along the line and this is the payback?

Well, for whatever reason I was pretty happy with my experience at Pi Bar.  Above average craft brew selection including Russian River Supplication and Blind Pig, Marin Brewing Tripel Dipsea and Porter and a few other selections.  

Personally I thought the pizza was great.  Pizza is kind of like BBQ in that if you're from some area that specializes in it, everything else will be crap.  This is better than your run of the mill pizza spot, nothing fancy like Delfina or Little Star, but easy, simple, fresh and not even close to being the bathtub of grease some places can be.  My friend and I got a large with a few meats and peppers and we enjoyed it thoroughly.

That said, the unfortunate part comes in that yes, this place seems to cater to the family and Marina types which I think kind of ruins how awesome this place could be.  If you're lucky enough to come early and snag a spot at the bar, the kid factor is easily less annoying but I do agree that this can be a deterrent for future visits.

Overall I really enjoyed coming here and will look to pick my times to come back and avoid the family/Marina scene... or at least get trashed before having to deal with it.
author: Steven R.

description:
Went to Pi Bar again last night and like aways it was awesome. Its a great place to go any night of the week, and its never 'too long' of a wait even when its packed you can always get a drink and stand at the bar. The food is fast and delicious. I recommend the pesto pi with olives. 

Great beer selection, you can always find something new on the list to try. Friendly and Fun staff do a great job. Its a great place to take friends visiting, or go on a date night. Will be back soon.
author: Bonnie P.

description:
I wonder why Pi is called "a bar" when the 3 times I've been here so were screaming children with their equally annoying parents.  Aren't there laws about minors in bars?  

The pizza is gigantic but doesn't taste like much of anything.  The toppings . . .where are they?  Hand me a magnifying glass please, because I don't see toppings.  

And while your at it, please tell that child to stop kicking at the wall.  It sounds like the building is being demolished.  So much for my relaxing bottle of wine and a pie . . .
author: Cinnamon Z.

description:
Another great bar down in the Mission. It may look a bit fancy, but the bartenders are very approachable and always willing to talk beer with you. The beer selection isn't large, but it's quality. 

I also suggest going to visit during a beer week event. Last year I went to the Russian River night. Although beyond crowded, the staff was unbelievably efficient and the beers were amazing and so reasonably priced.
author: Julie L.

description:
Nicely done, Pi Bar!

This is exactly the type of establishment I was looking to dine at the other night: low key, friendly, non-pretentious-San Francisco-bullshit employees, great pizza, GREAT beer selection, and very casual.  I found all of this, and more, at Pi Bar.

The service was exceptionally good--very friendly, casual, and speedy. The beer selection was vast. So vast that it was a little overwhelming. The pizza was very delicious.  Me and my two friends ordered a 21" pizza, and the slices were the way a good pizza slice should be--large.  I had two pieces and was stuffed.

Overall, this place gets two big thumbs up.
author: Andrew L.

description:
Alright Pi Bar, maybe its the beer talking but I think we can be friends.

After being turned down yet AGAIN at Mr. Pollo (what's with the hour plus wait times?!?) and being way south-er in the Mish than we normally are, we decided to give Pi Bar a shot.

7:30 pm on a Thursday, the place was full but we were encouraged to sit at some bar stools and have a drink until a space opened up.  Sit in a comfortable space and drink beer you say?  No problemo!  Shortly after we moved to a bar-height communal table and promptly ordered a large white pizza with bacon and onions.  Here's the breakdown:

Service:  lovely, attentive (to both drinks and food)

Food:  not too shabby-- I'd agree that the crust is a tad thick for my liking, but it happens to taste very good so they can get away with it.  Toppings were top-notch, loved the bacon with the balsamic onions, we were good orderers.  The size of the large is HUGE (we're big eaters, had 2 slices each and will have the other half tonight for dinner).

Price:  eh, I don't think this is Pi Bar's fault but I still have issue paying like, $30+ dollars for a pizza.  But the prices are the same as Little Star so I can't really fault them for it.

Atmosphere:  a little bland, but comfortable.  I could see myself happily sitting at the bar for a couple hours.  There's a good amount of space and nice communal tables so you definitely don't feel cramped or rushed at all.

Drinks:  Ah, here's where you win, Pi Bar.  Great microbrew selection.  Loved everything we tried.  

Also, I like the fact that you can get pizza by the slice here (I think its $3.50?).  Not a bad late night option, sit at the bar, drink a nice strong brew and eat a death by mushroom slice (which looked awesome).  Yes, please!
author: Kristin P.

description:
Yeah, the pizza's as lousy as everybody says. It somehow manages to be razor-thin, yet still have a crust that's not the least bit crispy or cracker-like. The toppings are so skimpy as to be almost non-existent. I don't understand why anyone would choose to put so little cheese and sauce on a slice.

Props for having Pranqster on tap, and the service was excellent. But still, even the pizza at Arnelli's is better.
author: Adam Z.

description:
Pi Bar appears from the outside to be anything but a restaurant but it is, I totally swear! I wasn't expecting too much when the service seemed uneven. The dude was helpful and friendly while the chick was aloof and ungrateful that she had guests, that she had a job. Maybe it was me though, some girls instantly take a antagonistic stance towards me but that's neither here nor there. Maybe she too exception to the girl I brought with me?
The pizza at Pi was thin crusted! The sauce was solid! The cheese was a dynamite! The toppings were good too. This was some damn good pizza. I didn't realize how much I liked the food until there weren't anymore slices left. This pizza is my kind of pizza!
My date informed me that this was typical pizza parlor pizza on the East Coast and it's about time she had a decent slice or two. (the date went down hill from there as she revealed how pushy and bitter she was) I just kept stuffing my pi hole.
The salad we started with was simple but the dressing was tangy and good. The garlic bread was delightful.

Yes, I want to come back here.
author: Alexander R.

description: This place gets a gold star for being awesome. The menu is short and sweet. The waiters are laid back. The beer list is always changing and always good. The pizza is unique and really fuckin good. It's better than delfina for sure, fuck that place.
author: William F.

description:
At first, the children running around was weird.  Now, I get a kick out of it.  Parents like to drink good beer and eat tasty pizza, too.  Stick with the Moonlight Death and Taxes mushroom pizza - delicious.

Closest place to Bernal for a great, unique craft beer list.  Their homebrew tasting was really fun, too.  I like the owners, the decor and the big front window with bar.

Sample the dog tolerates being tied up outside Pi pretty well - we hook her to the bike rack filled with bikes and babyseats.  Love it.
author: AP R.

description:
Pizza and beer.  I came here a couple of weeks ago because they were sponsoring Russian River Brewery and well of course i had to come and check it out. 

When i arrived they were already sold out of Pliny the younger, oh well they still had my favorite beer on tap Consecration!  I only came here for the beer and that's all that i had.  This place sponsors local brewery's from time to time, so i automatically have to give them mad props! 

The atmosphere was nice and they have a really long bar, everyone seemed to be eating pizza, drinking beer and having a good time.  The bar tenders were very friendly and you didn't have to wait very long for a drink.  This is not a very big restaurant, but at the same time it is called Pi Bar so it is more like a bar rather than a restaurant.  Next time i come here to enjoy some beer i will try the pizza and update my review but until than, this place has great beer.  Don't expect them to have Russian River Brews every night, but they will carry it from time to time. Happy Beer Month!!!
author: Skyler W.

description: Popped in recently for beer week and was pleasantly surprised by the ambiance and pizza slices. It was packed but my friend and I were able to get a seat at their big communal table in the front window. I was also surprised to get such speedy bar service considering how packed the place was and the bartender didn't flinch when I handed him my credit card. Great time, great beer and decent pizza. Looking forward to going back.
author: Nicole O.

description: My boyfriend had his first Delirium Tremens experience here the other night while we were entertaining some out of town guests. I can't tell if it was Pi or watching him pound through the 22oz bottle, only to realize how strong it was 20 minutes later that made the evening a success. Either way we had a great time, and the beer selection did not disappoint.
author: Lauren B.

description: Man, I feel bad for the people who've had bad experiences here, it's never been anything but the best for me. Always have good beer, all the pizza and snacks are fucking awesome to boot! And if you're really into east coast style pizza (thin, crispy crust, big slices meant to be folded to fit in your mouth) then this is it. Every person I've brought here that's originally from the east coast (including my father, who's spent a good deal of energy over the past 40+ years looking for a solid slice) loves this Pi. If you've had a bad time, I seriously recommend going back for a second chance, you shan't regret it.
author: Ian M.

description: Finally time to express my appreciation for this place. With a constantly rotating tap of craft beer from local brewers, a great slice and beer happy hour deal, friendly staff, and accepting of children; for a couple of beer-drinking parents, Pi Bar is a godsend. Thank you guys!
author: Cor D.

description: My boyfriend and I ordered a cheese pizza and side of garlic bread for more than $30 and both dishes sucked, to put it bluntly. Pi Bar is where I recommend you take your worst enemies--as long as they're paying. The environment is torturously loud, full of San Francisco Silicon Valley wonks. We were forced to move tables to allow a party of the aforementioned wonks to get sloppy drunk six inches away from us and were bordered on the other side by a man who spoke loudly of his sexual relationships the entire time we were there. No way could we understand anything we were trying to say to each other on our date night! What a horrible restaurant. One star for the bearded bus boy, who was the only person in the entire place to treat us with any sort of humanity.
author: J F.

description:
Pros, this place was opened pretty late on a weekday evening. It makes sense because it is a pizza parlor/bar. Interesting concept, decor was lacking and there really isn't much to look at in the restaurant. I would have given 3 stars, but we had to wait extremely long for food due to the staff burning our pizza the first time around and we were already starving upon our arrival.

- Fried mozzarella with pizza sauce: complementary due to our order mishap. They came in balls and not sticks like what I normally see at restaurants. Average, nothing special. 
- Italian Sausage and pepperoni pizza: Their large size (21") is great for sharing. I definitely liked the sausage pizza better than the pepperoni. There was more flavor, less grease, and their pizza is thin crust so not as filling. 

Service was slow and their pizza was okay, but nothing spectacular that impressed me. However, they do have a good beer selection along with quite a few special beers available.
author: Tracy T.

description:
Went here late night after watching a show at the Castro Theatre.  Very neighborhoody ( I know that's not a word but seemed appropriate hah)  feeling which is my kind of place.  Got the mushroom pizza....by the way the size of the pizzas are super generous...their small is pretty big....it would be a large at some other pizza places.....I didn't end up eating the pizza, but my friends really enjoyed it.  

They have a pretty cool beer selection and all in all I would totally come back here again especially if I live in the area.
author: Hanna J.

description:
The first time we dined at Pi Bar, it was great. The second time the pizza was burnt.
This is definitely not worth the money. Go some place else.
author: Terry M.

description: If this review was based solely on how tasty the food was, I'd have to give a five star rating but $7 for the Stromboli appetizer (which I thought was delish!) last night was ridiculous. The portion was three strips. That amounted to three bites, albeit big bites but still... Felt ripped off. (Pizza was priced right though.)
author: Mika S.

description:
They have a "Pi R Squared" special 3:14p - 6:28p daily. 
I had the Death by Mushroom Slice with Death and Taxes, the draft of the day. Verrry delicious. I actually ordered 2 specials. 

I wish they'd call the special "2PiR" instead, because then it actually makes sense --- 3.14 x2 = 6.28, and the radius varies by belly. =) Luckily most people won't notice, or care. Pi Bar has some great microbrews on tap, that's what really matters, right?! 

The rainbow cookies were delicious, they're like mini cakes. 
The Polenta Fries were tasty and filling. Good stuff.

It's nice when you go before 5pm because you'll have a seat at the bar before it gets packed.
author: Michelle W.

description:
I adore Pi Bar. It's not really trying to be like your neighborhood dive bar, but I end up USING it as a neighborhood dive bar, coming here by default when I don't know where else to go. I was here to watch the last game of the World Series (the owner had dragged in a flatscreen just for the occasion) and even though everyone in the bar were strangers to me, it felt like I was watching with friends. Oh yeah, and they poured glasses of champagne for everyone to toast when we won.

The beer selection is small, but very, very, very well selected. Basically there is always one of every major kind of beer on tap, and they are usually excellent choices from microbreweries both near and far. Any place that bothers to get Allagash White on tap will have repeat visits from me. Their selection changes regularly, though, so if they have something you like, drink up!

Of the food, I have had the pizza and the warm spinach salad, and both were excellent. I am not an East Coast Pizza Snob, but I have had such friends say fine things about the pizza here.
author: Colleen O.

description: Great spot for beer and pizza. I've only been once but plan on returning next time I'm in the mission district. Great selection on tap, triple voodoo grand cru knocks my socks off!
author: Barbara S.

description:
I'm not sure where I got the expectation that Pi Bar would actually be a restaurant.  It's really a dive bar that happens to serve food.  

The pizza is good but it's no Arinell's.  The spaghetti was tasty but it doesn't hold a candle to Emmy's.  And frankly, the Mission is full of dive bars.

Over-all I'd say that it was good enough but unremarkable.
author: Amy A.

description:
The food is decent.  And the beer list is their one redeeming quality.

Let's talk about the sorry excuse of a wait staff...We were there on a Tuesday rainy night.  There were 20 people there tops including our party of 6, ethnically diverse, and smoking hot women (we were a walking United Colors of Benetton ad, only hotter).  

The waitress (there were two of them)  both really interchangeable because there wasn't anything memorable about their personality nor face...could not be bothered to take our order of drinks and food...Hello Genius!  We were a large party and pretty sure looked like we were gonna spend the most money in that dump for that night so when we order a bottle and beers and food...You don't need to leave every 5 seconds after one of us orders something.  You don't piecemeal orders.  I mean what can the other dull face waitress say that would be so interesting that you had to rush by her side to hear?  

The crown of AWESOME service at Pi Bar has got to be that after they gave us our checks and we have tipped well...Dull waitress #1 came to our table to shut us up with this gem..."I am glad you are having fun, but can you keep it down?"  Now granted, we were pretty opinionated and we were having a good 'ol time...laughing up a storm...AND laughing loudly.  OOOHHH sorry, apparently at Pi Bar you are NOT allowed to guffaw a hearty, shrieking laugh.  God forbid these hipsters, sad wanna be waitresses learn to laugh and act silly in the middle of wearing their "way-too-tight" for their figure jeans.  Did it make her feel bigger to try to shut us up in front of her bearded regular crush?  Puhleaseee.  If you didn't want to listen...move away from our table...but generally speaking, sometimes when you are in a bar...People laugh loudly.  Is that news to you guys?  Mission people laugh too, you know?

Do yourself a favor, Pi Bar, get rid of these wait staff that take themselves waaaayyy too seriously.  You perhaps can benefit from someone who listens to Britney once a awhile with tack and know how to smile.  Better yet, I am just learning how to box, and I would love to spend 3 rounds in the ring with your wait staff :)  You really can benefit from better staff--1.)  that knows your beer 2.)  that knows the wine you carry 3.)  that have common courtesy.

Until then, you've lost our business.
author: Katrina N.

description:
.Pizza:  Pretty good.  Big,  thin crust (=good), tasty cheese.  Toppings can be bland.

Beer:  I hear it's good.  Not qualified to comment.

Service:  Improving.

Atmosphere: Foodie/Hipster/Noe/Tourist.  Whatev.
author: Joe B.

description:
Me and my posse dropped in here during our shopping spree yesterday and despite the "They Hate Us Yelp!" photo, this could not be further from the truth.  We were starved and pizza sounded like the just the thing to fill us up without emptying our purses. 
Couple of nice big slices of NY style pizza and we were ready recharged and ready to keep on going.  The décor is nothing special here, but it great for a pizza place and for dropping in for lunch or during a shopping spree. 
New York style pizza rules!
author: Nikki K.

description:
Are you Pi-curious?  Let me break it down for you.

EAT HERE IF:

* You like thin, chewy pizza with sparsely-distributed, high-quality toppings. 

* You like to drink.  And you appreciate an assortment of good beers and wines, not to mention servers who magically appear when your glass gets low and discreetly whisper in your ear, "Would you like another?"  Why, yes ma'am.  Yes, I would.  Enablers are the best!

* You would enjoy sitting in the front and gazing out on the old tack and feed store across the street (my  favorite building). OR you'd like to sit in the back and watch the pizza dudes tossing dough in the air. Fun stuff to look at!

* You think it's clever that a slice costs $3.14 and they open at 3:14.  Math jokes are funny!  

DON'T EAT HERE IF:

You prefer your pizza piled high with bell peppers, black olives, uncooked chunks of onion and CHEDDAR CHEESE.  There's a Round Table on San Bruno Ave you'd probably prefer.  Listen, I'm not hating.  I share a bathroom and my destiny with someone who loves that kind of pizza.  But I don't get it -- and you won't get it at Pi bar.  If you've ever eaten bacon on a pizza, I am looking at you!
author: Rosie W.

description: Went here last night for the first time after recently moving to the Mission and loved it! Started with the pretzel which was smaller than i would have liked but tasty. Then I had the spinach salad and the bf had the lasagna - both were awesome. I definitely am coming back for the pizza but its awesome that they have so many other great options. The beer selection was good too - Russian River Blind Pig never disappoints. It looked like there was a decent bottle selection too.
author: Lizzie S.

description: Had the mushroom pizza (and don't remember the other), but they were really fresh. The beer selection was pretty good. I suppose it changes frequently since it was written on a chalk board. Street parking is available. Staff are all pleasant to deal with.
author: Andrew Y.

description: Good pizza -- reasonably priced.  Convenient location to the BART, which is always nice.
author: Mel G.

description:
Can you hear me?  I feel like I need to shout this review.  IT IS REALLY LOUD IN THIS PLACE!  I don't personally like places where you have to yell to be heard from 6 inches away.  I also don't like restaurants that don't have any culinary vision.  All the pizzas are "build your own" - which is a nice option, but I prefer to have suggestions on the menu - at the very least to indicate that they know what they think pizza should taste like.  

The pizza tasted fine, and does and adequate job mimicking "New York Style" thin crust.  It's on par with Arinelle's but the crust is far inferior to Delfina (it's all crispy and no chewy).  We got half of our pizza plain to see how they master the basic, and interestingly, the side that was plain was covered in pools of grease that dripped everywhere when you picked up a slice.  I have never been, and hope never to be a pizza blotter, but I was pretty tempted here.  I'm no prospector, but forget offshore, set up your drill on a slice of Pi.  Usually, I bemoan impotent pizza (when the tip can't stand up to the weight of the pizza and droops) because it's overladen with toppings - in this case, it seemed just to be grease causing the soggy tip.

I also take issue with the identity crisis of sorts that this place experiences.  The beers are fancy and expensive, complete with matching glasses, the music is so loud that you expect a dance floor, and yet uniformed wait staff is serving up what are essentially street slices at candle lit tables.  The mismatched plates are reminiscent of a mom and pop Italian restaurant, but the rest of the decor is minimal and bar like.  

I'd probably eat the pizza there again (provided there is no wait), but wouldn't go out of my way.  As an establishment, I find Pi to be confused and unfocused, but maybe that's intentional and I just don't get it.  Oh well, in the meantime, Little Star and Delfina still reign supreme, and hey Serrano's delivers.
author: Linda L.

description:
As you walk in, the long open wooden hallway calls out bar, yet a look to your left looks like your standing outside a pizza parlor.  Confusing, very confusing. 

But to give it the benefit of the doubt, I think that's probably what they were going for.  I came here with Danny P. and Tracy T, and another friend to see how the pizza and beer was.  Big thumbs up to the beer, but ehh on the pizza.  It's not great pizza, but its just your typical average.  I think its definitely worth coming here on the days they have specials since that's when you'll get your money's worth for a slice of dough and sauce sprinkled with stuff on top.

Beer! - it came out $9 for a glass of Hoptimum which does not taste far from what it sounds.  it truly is hoppy and strong too.  I'd have to say Pi Bar is definitely worth coming here for the beers which are hard to find anywhere else, and if anything, the main attraction would have to be just that and the pizza is there just to compliment it.
author: Vincent K.

description:
Go for the beer.

I really want to write a better review and give away those poor sad extra stars, but I just can't.

I went with a group of 5 girls during beer week. We intentionally went early to avoid the rush (success)... BUT THEN, no one greeted us.  We just looked around sad and confused for a few minutes until some other friendly diners helped us out by moving their small group to a smaller table, evacuating 5 spots for us.

We ordered great beer - the waiter was very knowledgeable on the selections and helped us pick the best brews (success)... BUT THEN, when we ordered the 2nd round, he just forgot to bring them to us (fail).

Overall, the food was fine. Not great, but pizza was fairly tasty with mushroom sauce and lots of veg topping options (they can even do 1/2 and 1/2). 

So. Go for the beer, but for my $, I'll get my food elsewhere.
author: Gretchen S.

description:
Good stuff!!!  I've been here twice, the first time having wandered in because a place called Pi (open from 6:28 to 3:14) must have some kind of sense of humor.  

The bartenders were nice and helpful, the polenta fries where interesting, if a little too oily.  The pizza...well there goes my 5th star.  I'm a NYer and I like NY pizza.  While this may appear to be NY pizza, it's way too sweet to qualify.  Yes, sweet.  I think the tomato sauce they put on the pizza is strange and not savory enough.  And crust was a little tough...but whatever I wasn't expecting Di Fara's or anything.

I'll be back!
author: Samantha G.

description:
To address some of the negative comments I've read:

Yeah, it'll probably be crowded and loud...if you show up on a Saturday night. It's a bar in the Mission! I don't like crowded bars either, but rather than blame a business for doing well, you know what I do? I go when it's not crowded! Use your brain.

The beer selection is very delicious. The service is very hospitable. In all likelihood, if you feel you're being mistreated, it's probably something you did. Are you one of those people who gets the bartender's attention just to reveal you still don't have your order figured out?

As far as the pizza goes: Giving your own opinion about pizza is stupid. Almost as stupid as listening to someone else give theirs. People have different tastes. Pi Bar's pizza is thin, crispy, and made with quality ingredients. If that sounds good to you, go eat it. Make your own decision. If you don't like it they have plenty on tap to wash it down.
author: Chad F.

description:
If you're the kind of guy who say San Francisco pizza can't compare to New York pizza, let me be the first to label you a prick.  That's right, Pi Bar miraculously figured out how to make flour, yeast, tomato sauce, and cheese in SF taste like flour, yeast, tomato sauce, and cheese in NY.  

  "Oh but there's just something about NY pizza"  No, pizza is the control variable in this equation, you are still the prick.   

  Pi Bar is awesome, it's a great addition to the neighborhood in much need of a warm, welcoming, unpretentious, place to grab a beer and a slice with a friend and shoot the shit without having to scream over crappy music.
author: Lake C.

description:
Yay Im a fan! even if I am not a big fan of beer. Their Beer on Tap selection is excellent and not serve us much compared to other Brewcos.

The pizza is great as well. The place is small and it gets crowded early. It will take you forever to get seats even at the bar but on a Friday or Saturday night, its all good.

You must try this place.
author: Malou C.

description:
Not really sure what all the fuss is about, to be quite honest.

Sure, they have a great selection of beer, but everyone in the Mission at least has a decent one these days. The pizza? Mediocre at best - quite greasy I thought and no where near the caliber of other pizza establishments in the neighborhood. The caesar salad was the worst part; lettuce with, um, nothing really. 

I guess I had higher expectations since so many people I know frequent the joint and seem to love it. I left feeling disappointed and wouldn't recommend it to my friends.
author: Zara E.

description: I absolutely love Pi Bar!  The beer selection is outstanding - I've recently discovered an affinity for dark Belgian ale, and Pi Bar always satisfies my craving.   My beer geek friends especially adore this establishment for its extensive, thoughtful selection of imported and local brews.  The owner Jen is friendly and kind, and often pours me a free glass of her newest offering on tap.  The environment is cozy, comfortable and well-lit, although it can get rather crowded at the usual times.
author: icka b.

description:
Pizza that doesn't disappoint. 

I'm a tough customer for pizza, and I have to say that I was a skeptic about a pizza that didn't included tomato sauce. Seems wrong in my book. Still, the Death by Mushroom pizza is a solid winner. Mushroom reduction sauce and cheese, add onions and mushrooms (of course), and put it on top of a wonderful thinner crust and the result is pretty darn tasty. 

The anchovy appetizer is pretty petite as you get only 2-1/2 fishies that are quite pickled. Be prepared. 

The pretzel is also petite, and the polenta fries are an okay sized portion, but a bit light on flavor. 

Though the app's are just okay, the pizza rocked, and be prepared if you order the large. When they say 21 inches, they mean a full 21 inches. 

Yum. I'll be back.
author: Tim P.

description:
I went there for the beer week and they do have amazing selection of beers. The wait staff is knowledgabl about beers and will make recommendation based on what you like. They do have special selctions, brewmaster nights. Be careful with doubl IPAs and double bocks they do pack a punch and some of ther have hight alcohol volume than Wine

We also ordered a slice of pizza, nothing to write about it. The recommendation is to order the full Pi. Maybe next week.
author: Subhash J.

description:
Another nice addition to the Mission pizza brigade on a block that gets freakishly quiet once the sun goes down.

This one's ever-so-slightly less yuppie, if only because it looks more like a tavern and has way more draught beers than wine.

Deux Amis zinfandel was good, but I'll give the beers a shot next time. Spinach salad with house-made Italian sausage and feta was an excellent start. Two of us finished an entire pizza, which means it was either delicious or manageable enough to do so (it was both, for the record). Hand-thrown thin crust with portabello mushrooms and pepperoni hit the spot. Pi doesn't have an insane list of original and wacky toppings, but I'm way into this place.

Note: adorable, clever specials deserve a mention. $3.14 (get it?!) for a slice of cheese pizza, and $6.28 2-Pi-"R"egular: a slice and the beer of the day.
author: Tara R.

description:
Pi, thank you for the expansive local beer selection and tasty NY-style pizza.  The pizza is nowhere near Pizzeria Delfina or Farina's caliber, but it's quite good nonetheless.

No thank you for the 45 min wait for seating!  I will avoid you on Friday and Sat nights but am optimistic about you on weekdays.
author: Sid D.

description:
I like that there's a place on Valencia that isn't a big scene where you have to wait a half hour to get in and sit down.  Sure, Pi is sometimes crowded, but generally I can find a place to sit right away.

The beer selection is quite good.  If the Tornonado had only a dozen beers or so, they would be Pi.

They have a lot of comfort food, all of it pretty solid but not outstanding.  The one exception is a warm spinach and sausage salad, which is one of my favorite dishes in the city.

The pizza is convenient and sold by the slice.  It's decent, but the crust seems a bit dry.  Arinell is three times better pizza.

Atmosphere wise, the glass put on top of the veneer bar is kind of tacky.

But for ease of dining, lack of pretentiousness on Valencia St.,  well-chosen beer selection, and that fantastic spinach and sausage salad I give it four stars.
author: Paul S.

description:
First things first: the name pi is not clever and the use of pi related numbers as a marketing ploy is annoying.

Pi is a wonderfully stocked beer joint.  Lots of interesting brews in a comfortable drinking space with perfectly attentive staff making sure you're constantly well taken care of. 

Unfortunately the pizza isn't great.  The pies (or pis) certainly aren't bad and there isn't anything actively wrong with them. but they could use a bit of oomph. Maybe they need to add the necessary E to their name.  I could stop being annoyed at the name and perhaps the pies would get better...
author: Mat K.

description:
Pizza snob says:

Slices = meh
Whole pie = not bad... but not awesome.

**IN THEIR DEFENSE:  I know they were having some serious issues with their oven for a while, which of course would have a huge impact on the pizza.

As a B&R New Yorker, I was SO SO SO excited for the opening of this place.  I live close by, and dammit, there are precious few good places to grab a slice!  Hearing that one of the owners hailed from Brooklyn and wanted to do NY-style-by-the-slice and a no fuss menu, I was esctatic--  Alas, the pizza is but a shadow of my beloved pie.  It sure LOOKS like NY pizza, but the texture of the crust is not quite up to snuff.  Soft, a little doughy... no crunchy crackle.  It's NOT BAD, but not at all what I was expecting.

However:  They have DELICIOUS toppings including home-made meatballs and sausage, and a killer beer selection.  It's a great place to hang out, the owners and staff are nice as can be, and they literally just opened-- I think it's fair to assume it will take a while before they are a well-oiled machine.  

In the mean time, I like it here!  Spectacular pizza or not, this is still a great place to have in the neighborhood, and I can't help but wish them all the best.
---------
NERD MOMENT: Suggestion to the owner:

You have cleverly named your happy hour special "Pi (R) Squared" and are charging $6.28.  I get what you're going for:  It's a play on the equation for the area of a circle.  But there are 2 things:

1.  Pi squared is not $6.28 (that's Pi times 2).  Pi squared is 9.86.

2. "R" is the key number in the equation, and obviously the R doesn't have anything to do w/ the special.

So:  I propose you change the name of the special to "2 Pi R", which is the equation for the circumference of a circle... aaaand just tell people who are huge nerds (such as myself) that R = 1.

Ta-da!

::end nerd transmission::
author: Laura F.

description:
I guess I should have known better than to go to a bar for pizza.... 

Yeah, definitely not the best pizza place in the city. We left hungry and not satisfied.

It's not cheap, It's dirty and way too dark in there.
author: Minie J.

description:
Shared a pizza and a Caesar salad. 

Food: The salad was good, but nothing special. The pizza had a nice thin crust and flavorful pepperoni, but the sauce and other toppings (peppers and Parmesan) were only fair. The beer list was mediocre. 

Service: Very good. Prompt and friendly.

Ambiance: Basic pizza joint ambiance. Not as loud as I thought it was going to be.

Price: It seemed kind of pricey, but there was a decent amount of food.
author: Yogi B.

description:
This place is not trying to be something it's not. Here's what they're not pretending to be:

*  Gourmet Pizza for foodies
*  Sceenster hangout
*  Fancy brunch place for wine-swilling yuptards

I had my reservations about this place mostly because of the buzz on SF blogs and on yelp.  I don't really want to stand in line for dinner AND certainly don't want to hang out with a bunch of rich, food loving yuppies whose focus in life is being the first to eat at a new restaurant and then trash it for not being cool enough. ugh.

Anyway. Pi Bar isn't like that.  

It's a relaxed bar, with no ESPN, where you can grab a nice beer and a slice of pizza.

Take it for what it is, and enjoy.
author: Krissy M.

description:
I live around the corner from Pi. I was sad when Suriya Thai closed up because it was a-friggin-mazing, but excited to have a cool new place coming in its place.  

So...the pizza was pretty decent.  As opposed to Arinell's at 16th and Valencia, this place has a long way to go on its crust, which is the cornerstone of any good pie (or pi).  If there's no cracker crispiness to the crust, and I'm throwing away the crust after the goodies are eaten, then you are 0 for 2 in what makes a good crust.  The toppings were great - portobella mushrooms and sausage were the highlights.  The sauce and overall pie had good flavor.  

But here's the stunner:  I grabbed a couple of pizzas to bring home to watch Monday night football with a few friends.  That's two pizzas and nothing else.  No beer.  No soda.  No salad.  No happy ending.  Nada.  After tax and tip it was $70.  HOLY MOTHER OF MARY!  That's WAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAY too much for two medicocre pizzas.  They should disclaim that they are fleecing you when you call in a to order to-go.
author: Adam C.

description:
Similar in style to Arinell, heavy on the cheese with not enough sauce for my taste. Our large sausage pie was HUGE, more than enough for 3. Some slices had crispy crust but others were soggy from the excess cheese. The outer crust was too thick for me and I left it uneaten, but the rest of the crust was fine.

They have a daily slice and beer special.
author: Derrick V.

description:
Great beer selection, good service, and good NY style pizza for SF.

if the lasagna is the special for the night you're there, GET IT.
author: Sean K.

description:
Back in the day (mid-1990s) when I first arrived in San Francisco, I was astonished to find that it was essentially impossible to get good pizza here. Fortunately, the situation has dramatically improved in the past 14 years, and now the Mission, formerly a desert of pizza sadness and abandonment, has become perhaps the best part of town to forage for a good pie.

So of course I'd been thoroughly looking forward to visiting this place Pi Bar: oh boy! Allegedly good pizza, closer to where I live than the other influx of recent (and generally awesome) pizza arrivals in the Mission. And with good beer, too? Sign me up!

My first disappointment was with the atmosphere of the place. It's a large space, painted a putrid ochre colour that's hard on the eyes. With the carpets and wall hangings that the predecessor tenant Suriya used to damp echoes all replaced by hard surfaces, the place is noisy and jangly to the nerves.

Also, that indefinable something in a place's atmosphere? In this case, that special numinous quality is completely absent, and the place feels like it would fit well into a mall in a small town outside Boston (having been to such places).

The service, on the other hand, was good: thoroughly friendly, attentive, quick, and professional. I was definitely happy on that front.

The selection and quality of beers was decent, but not in any way spectacular: it's not at all out of line for the Mission, and wouldn't hold a candle to any self-respecting bar in Portland. So while I was pleased with the drinks, don't buy the hype that Pi's beer selection is above average.

And now on to the pizza, which was a solid disappointment. They have two sizes, huge (15") and ridiculous (20"), which means you really need a party of two starving people to make much progress on even the 15". And the actual quality of the pizza was absolutely mediocre: not in any way a step up from some hole-in-the-wall by-the-slice joint (actually worse than some), and no threat to the new pizza hotness represented by Beretta or Pizzetta 211. The crust was chewy and soggy, the cheese was too heavy, and there wasn't enough sauce. Ugh.

I'm trying to think of something good to say about the place in conclusion beyond "they were professional and didn't give me food poisoning", but honestly, I wouldn't go back.
author: Bryan O.

description:
Total disappointment. I live about half a block away and have been looking forward to this place opening since Surya closed. I had thought, well I thought I had read something, on Eater that some hot-shot chefs were behind this place, so I was thinking that it might give Beretta a run for its money. Not so much. Overall impression, starting with the decor, food, etc. everything about this place seemed completely amateur and lackluster. 

Honestly, the pizza is about on par with the crappy stuff I consumed when I was in college, at about 2am and after many beers. For about 1/30 the price, I'd have to say that even Katz's or Arinell's pizza is about 10 times better - and frankly, for this price, the pizza better be creative and artisanal. Not so much. 

And, the non-pizza stuff on the menu was sort of hodge podge and boring (but expensive). Weird. Beside the cutesy $3.14 for a cheese slice, this place seems like not a whole lot of thought went into it, which is strange for any new restaurant doing business in SF.
author: chloe w.

description:
Upfront disclaimer: this is not going to be one of those hairsplitting expositions on how the slices at Pi are not everything that some mythical pizza place in Brooklyn used to be in my romanticized imagination.

The husband and I stopped in for a quick bite before heading down to a Sharks game. For less than $25, we had three delicious slices and three beers per the happy hour special. The slices were not mythical, but totally delicious. The beer selection is excellent and has a number of seldom-seen items and great variety. The service was friendly, fast and attentive. The crowd was diverse - a neighborhood guy in his 60s reading the Financial Times, hipsters, families with young children. Everyone seemed welcome.

I had a great time and fully expect to put Pi in the regular rotation. Two quick suggestions - perhaps add some sound dampeners as it did get really loud, and maybe adjust the tables across from the bar to fit in a bit more seating. Otherwise, a great addition to the neighborhood!

P.S.  It's across the street from Anthony's Cookies, so save room.
author: Valerie W.

description:
This place has delicious pizza, but due to the *atrocious* service by the bartender/host, I will think twice before coming back.

My brother and I came here last Friday night for what was supposed to be a quick dinner.  I put our names down on the list and was pleased to see that there weren't TOO many people in front of us.  We hung out at the bar and waited for our table, declining the bartender's offer to eat at the bar, since it appeared that we would be able to get a table without too long of a wait.  After about 10 minutes, I noticed that 3 tables had opened up.  Since we were the third party on the list, I assumed that meant that we were up.

We gave up our place at the bar and made our way to the front of the restaurant.  The bartender/host (the same one who had earlier asked us if we wanted to eat at the bar) seated the two parties of two in front of us at two-person tables.  He then proceeded to completely ignore us and go back to the bar.  No explanation.  No eye contact.  We thought that maybe he just really needed to do something at the bar, but no.  Completely ignored us.  Mind you, there was a table sitting unoccupied and clean and there was NOBODY behind us in line.  Sure it was a table for 4, but there was NOBODY else who was waiting for a table.

About 10 minutes later, a group of 3 came in.  The bartender/host came to the front of the restaurant, still completely ignoring us and refusing to make eye contact, and asked them if they had another person in their group, ready to give them that table for 4.  They stated that they did not, so he asked them if they would like to sit at the bar and eat there.  They then went to where we had been sitting at the bar and took those seats.  It would have been GREAT if the rude bartender/host had actually told us that their policy was to not seat parties of 2 at a table for 4 so we could have taken those seats and started our meal.  But no, still no eye contact.

Another 10 minutes passed.  We had now just been standing for 20 minutes at the front of the restaurant and noticed to our dismay that all of the tables for two had JUST been seated.  At this rate, it was going to be awhile.  I was fuming.  The bartender/host walked past us again (yep, STILL no eye contact or acknowledgment of our existence), and finally my brother tapped him and asked if we could just be seated there since there was NOBODY behind us in line.  He explained that their policy was to not seat parties of two at 4-person tables.  Ok, I understand if they're busy, but I cannot reiterate enough how ridiculous it was considering we were the ONLY ones waiting!  Also, parties of two are MUCH more likely to cruise in to a restaurant looking for a table on a Friday night than parties of 4!  

FINALLY, a little over 1/2 an hour after we got there, we were seated at the table for 4.  Please note that at no point during our meal did a party of 4 come in looking for a table.

The food itself was quite good, though the kitchen dropped our pizza at some point and had to remake it.  They compensated us with free refills on our wine.  But what was supposed to be a short dinner ended up being QUITE long and frustrating.  

Though I really enjoyed the food (we got a cheese pizza with roasted peppers, balsamic onions, and portabello mushrooms - QUITE tasty), I don't think I will be coming back for awhile.  I cannot believe a place can stay open for business when the host is so rude that he won't even make eye contact with the customers or give any kind of explanation about why they can't have an OPEN table when nobody else is around.
author: Julie S.

description:
I was pretty thoroughly disappointed after the hype about this place...paying .75 cents more for a mediocre slice of pizza based on a math equation is a bit too pretentious hipster even for me (and I'm known to be quite a sucker, honestly). To be brutally honest, I've had better pizza from a frozen cardboard box. Maybe my slice was just old? Though in the time they took to "heat it" according to the server (about 10 minutes), Serrano's makes a better one from scratch.

Arinell's still reigns supreme as the best New York-style pizza in the Mission. I'll even take toothless employees of questionable hygiene and flourescent lighting over this place. 

Bummer!
author: Melissa G.

description:
The sauce has flavor and the toppings are fresh, but the crust is just totally lacking and not at all "New York Style".  

What a disappointment!  Especially considering the price....$35 for one large pizza with two toppings.  

Sorry Pi, that's just IRRATIONAL.
author: Liz T.

description:
Pi Bar is a great local place. I have been many times and have always had a great experience. The beer's change pretty regularly so it is always nice to go in and try something different. The pizza is good and I suggest switching up the toppings from time to time. 

A+++++
author: Will B.

description:
My 2 friends had been wanting to try Pi Bar for a while.  Overhyped.  They had nothing bad to say about it, but I think this place doesn't hold a candle to what was easy to get many places when I lived in NY.  If you're pizza-hungry in san francisco, search hard and expect disappointment.  

Let me start with the good:

-Sauce had more flavor and spice than the usual around here.  (That's always my #1 complaint... a lot of places do it like spaghetti sauce - uggh, ew, sweet.)  Decent but not great.

-Crust wasn't over-doughy or soggy, and earned points from my friends compared to other local places I haven't been.

-Cheese was a reasonable amount.

-Portabella mushroom topping was well prepared.

The bad:

-Cheese was dry and plastic-y.  That sheen of grease you get on a good, cheesy (even cheap and generic) pizza might be too much for you, but go ahead and blot it if so.  I love it... and it should bubble together with the sauce.  Of course, we did have takeout and waited to eat, so it wasn't super warm when we did.  It would be better straight from the oven, but I love a good pizza even when it's cold, and this failed to impress.   

-Crust was tasteless, dry and cracker-y.  Nice try for thin NY style, but I NEVER leave the end of crusts, and I couldn't choke this down even with copious beer.

-Sauce did not complement the crust and cheese due to those drawbacks.  You could load in more spice and amount to compensate, but it would be the wrong balance.  

I would like Pi Bar to get a pie from Pavones in Syracuse NY to see how it's done... just to name one random place barely anybody here would know, that doesn't need hype or cost to be great.  http://www.yelp.com/biz/pavones-pizza-syracuse

Local pizza I liked ok- Uncle Vitos, Little Star, Arinell.
author: Pat L.

description:
If I was yelping Pi Bar based on service and price alone, I'd give three or four stars. The woman helping me was super friendly, and I'm a fan of the $3.14 slice price. A well done wink to their name.

Unfortunately that slice was not so good. Gross, actually. Things started so well when I was told they were made fresh, so I asked for light on the cheese. But my slice looked just like any other, even though the woman asked if it was light enough. I didn't know what to say. Not to mention grease was already dripping through the wax paper on both sides. I wasn't about to ask them to remake it. I bolted, and once home used about two rolls of paper towels to soak up as much grease and cheese as possible.

I realize I'm more particular than most with this stuff, but I'm not sure many of you would find that much grease appealing. At least sober.
author: Jason B.

description: Pi Bar is a cool hangout, with a manageable selection of good beer, and a kitchen that turns out tasty pizza.  You can order by the slice, which is nice if you're not too hungry.  I recommend the polenta fries if you're looking for a starter.
author: Dan W.

description:
Man, my heart sank when I read those negative reviews. I don't understand how so many people don't like the pizza. It's thin crust, deliciously crispy on the bottom, and they have fantastic toppings. My regular is balsamic onions and Neuske's smoked bacon. The Caesar salad is delicious as well. If you have to have broccoli rabe on your pie, LittlePaulinesDelfinaStar will probably be more your speed, but Pi's crust take's me back to my favorite digs in NYC. The only time I've been mildly disappointed was with Death by Mushroom. Needs some kind of acid to pick it up a bit.

Fortunately no one will argue that the beer isn't the bomb. Always a good double/imperial IPA to brighten my evening. Jennifer, the owner, is a serious beer connoisseur and a pleasure to chat with. Take a second to ask her about the newest collaborations they're doing with regional brewers. 

Does get pretty packed from 7-9 Thursday through Saturday, so expect a line if you're a bigger party. If not, bar is almost always available for one to three people.

I'm always surprised to see families in there, because it gets loud when it's busy, but almost every time I've been in I've seen kids, lots of them adolescent.
author: Matthew R.

description:
I like Pi Bar. It's in walking distance of my home, and it's casual. Pi Bar is a bar first, a pizza restaurant second. The beer selection is cool and there's something for everyone (if you drink beer). My partner & I managed to get two seats at the bar on Friday at around 6:30PM. We ordered a small pie and thought it was good. Not the best accommodations for taking leftovers with you, though. We had a couple slices left, and all they had was wax paper. 

I'll probably be back for a beer or two, and it's nice they serve pizza by the slice, which isn't always easy to find in San Francisco. With Anthony's Cookies across the street, this block is cornering the market for carbs.
author: Eileen B.

description:
I came to Pi Bar twice this past week with a couple of friends because they were sampling two of our favorite breweries, Anderson Valley and Russian River, for SF beer week.  The place is a little small and doesn't have to much seating but we were able to find a spot at the bar. It took a while to grab the bartender's attention because they were really busy, but once we did they were really friendly and got us our beers quick. The beers were excellent, poured perfectly and not overpriced.

The pizza is classic thin crust New York style and can be ordered by the slice, or by a whole pizza.  We were given a piece the first night by a fellow bar patron who had some left.  The second night we ordered our own slices with bacon and Italian sausage.  Both nights the pizza was fantastic.  They get extra points for using actual slices of bacon and not bacon bits like most places.  

I think I'll be coming here much more often from here on out for more pizza, and to try the different beers that come and go.
author: Bill U.

description:
I had high expectations for this place after reading their manifesto (as the founders call it) on Pi Bar's website, which declared that there was no good pizza in SF. Gasp! So I was ready to be saved from this alleged dearth of sub-par SF pizza and expected to be wowed after the big game they talked online.

Alas, I was not. All the food we had (a salad, polenta fries and a large pie) were all good, but not the level of amazing that I expected. The pizza was still quite greasy and none of the flavors were particularly exciting.

However, to their credit, they do have a terrific selection of beers, and the geek in me gives them props for having a 3.14-centric theme.

In spite of being underwhelmed, I'll probably go back for a beer and a slice as part of their "Pi R Square" deal.

And for the record, SF does have amazing pizza. It's called Pizzeria Delfina! This new kid on the block pizza establishment betta recognize!
author: Rachel G.

description:
I went here on opening night, so I'm sure they were still perfecting their service- however I was really pleased and will definitely be back often. The pizza was really good, though I will say that even as a small lass, one slice wasn't enough for me, you'll probably want to get a whole pie if you're not dining solo. Me and my dining companion also split a Caprese salad, which I found to be overpriced (it was $13 for a very small salad) but tasty. Atmosphere was nice- a small number tables and bar seating- might be difficult to get a table once business picks up. It would be great if they had like a grab and go option for slices so one could drop by after work or before the bars to grab something on the quick,

Also, delicious Anthony's cookies is nearby so you can have a great little night of junk food :)
author: Kate P.

description:
So went to Pi Bar this weekend which was recommended by Voldemort who we were meeting up with in the city. 

The first thing I noticed which gave me quite a laugh was the sign on their window which said "The People on Yelp Hate Us!" or something to that statement. We arrived at 9:45pm and there was plenty of room we grabbed seats at the bar and first thing I noticed was the large variety of non-brand name beers and lots of local micro brews. 

It took about 5 minutes for the bartender to take our order and present us with the menu. We scanned the drinks available and made our orders, I got a dark lager called Death & Taxes from Moonlight Brewing. Before ordering I asked about the beverage whether it was heavy or not and the bartender told me it was dark but still a lager and not heavy. Personally I can't remember a dark beer that wasn't heavy but I took her advice and ordered a pint. Voldemort's friend ordered a high alcohol content beverage named "Monk's Blood", however it came served in what appeared to be a wine glass and about a third the size of my pint glass. They should put a warning next to the brew stating it comes in a third pint, but they don't list that anywhere and still charge you the normal $5/drink. Overall $5 per drink at a place like this isn't terrible especially because of the selection of micro brews. 

Voldemort and I each then ordered a slice of pizza, which based on my quick read through the menu is made using sustainable ingredients or some other sort of green method of agriculture and cooking. The pizza took about 10 mins or so and the slices look large, size is similar to a slice at Escape from New York. I got a Mushroom and Olive and Voldemort got a Pepperoni and Mushroom. Overall I thought the pizza was lacking real taste, texture was similar to Tomatina (Walnut Creek) but really the flavor seemed lost. Voldemort did enjoy her piece however but was unable to finish so I did it for her as that is apparently my role in the home . . . Garbage Disposal cause I'll basically eat anything even if I don't like it. 

After we completed our meal it took a long time for the bartender to bring us our bill, which displeased Voldemort cause she was anxious to get home to kill Harry Potter! 

Once arriving home I felt terrible, not because of the pizza, but rather the beer that was actually very heavy despite the bartender's comment it was not. I really did feel like Death & Taxes so I can't fault the brewer but the bartender should know the product she's selling. 

Overall given the opportunity I would pass on going back to Pi unless I had a reason or a friend guilt trips me into it.
author: Mark K.

description:
Decent selection of beer, I had wine. Haven't tried the pizza yet but cleaner then most bars.

went there a second time...wish i could bump it up to a 4 but might need to try again.
author: Tiff W.

description:
I wanted to like Pi Bar.  I really did!  I LOVE pizza, and they could have filled a niche in our stellar pizza neighborhood.  But... meh.  The crust was hard and flavorless - I even left the outer crust on my plate because it was so chewy and unpalatable.  And the cornicione is usually my favorite part!  It tasted like they have some kind of humidity control issues in their oven, combined with overly long cooking times?  Or maybe they've got some flour protein/gluten issues?  The cheese and sauce also lacked any redeeming character.  Major bummer.

Clearly these guys care a lot about what they're doing, so I really hope they tweak their recipe to something that's worth the price they're charging.  Based on their website manifesto I believe they want to excel, so maybe I'll give them another try in a month or so after they've settled a bit.
author: Jess L.

description:
Favorite Pizza:  Death By Mushrooms (add the house made sausage for extra win!)

I love this place. Great New York style pizza and craft brew beers on tap!

Everyone is so nice here (that's worth a lot in and of itself), and I just love the atmosphere.  They play nice music, but at a reasonable volume.

What a great place! I totally think that for the Mission, this is as good as it gets! Woooooooooo!
author: C H.

description:
You don't have to drag me to try Pi Bar.

All I can say is... DELICIOUS!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

I had:
Polenta Fries A+++
Meatballs A
Pizza with bacon A+++ so good my rabbi forgave me.

I will be back. Beer selection is awesome too.

Thank goodness that #@$#@ Thai place shut down and these guys came in!
author: A. E.

description:
Got a pie from Pi Bar.
The large is very large.
It reminds of New York slices.
The ingredients were fresh.
The dough was tough..
The crust was good.
Your average slice.
author: Po L.

description:
Really this is a beer bar that serves pizza, not a pizza restaurant that serves beer.

At least, I was a lot more impressed by the beer selection than the pizzas.

The pizzas were, overall, fine, but not what I'd expect after a restaurant that chose its name from the sacred circle. (I think Beretta, just down the street, not only has much better pizza -- which is not surprising -- but at a better price, which is surprising.)

Also, they have exactly 5  tables (plus one communal table at the front, and the bar), so there's not a lot of seating and it doesn't take a large crowd before it's gone... be prepared to wait if you want a table. If you saw this space when it was Suriya, you'll probably be mystified, as I was, as to where all the space went. (OK, it went to the bar, the visible kitchen, and more space between the tables. Still, I'm not sure it was a good tradeoff.)

I'll probably go back for the beer but not the pizza.
author: Matt G.

description:
Great beers!  These guys have the perfect selection of Belgian and Belgian style beers without crushing you with a huge amount of options.  It's clear they put in a lot of thought into this part of the experience, I'd say it's a bar first, pizza place second.

The pizza was pretty good, but there were some flaws that my critical tongue pointed out to me.  My main problem is that there is no character to the crust.  It's either soggy at the super thin center, or it's cardboard cracker hard at the edges.  I found the dough to be too floury, it left a semi grainy taste in my mouth.  I left the crust, you wouldn't want to eat it.  The cheese was great and the sauce was nice too.  The small size is huge - 15 inches - so as an individual, go for the slices, they looked bigger and better anyway.  And the slice deal they have everyday can't be beat, slice and a great beer for $6.24.

This place has a great feel, nice open space with plenty of room at the bar, the community table or you can probably get a table for yourselves with a short wait.  The people here are super nice, and they take a huge pride in the overall experience.  They are passionate about the beer, and that goes a long way.  They will improve the pizza, because they have to, but that should be the easy part.  They have the vibe down and it's only going to get better!
author: Jon S.

description:
Personally I would give Pi Bar 3 stars, but I don't drink beer (at this point in my life...maybe one day my bum stomach will allow me to drink once more) so it didn't seem fair for me to be rating it as someone who can't enjoy the whole experience. The $6.28 beer of the day and slice deal is an amazing bargain, esp. since the day we went the beer was an expensive high alcohol barley wine. 
The garlic bread was really good, but I wasn't blown away by the pizza. I've had way better thin crust and the toppings I tried weren't great .
There aren't a lot of tables and it was starting to get really crowded at 5pm on a Friday so if I were to revisit Pi Bar I would definitely  come for a late lunch.
author: Lauren T.

description:
Second times a charm at this place.
Heres what you do:
1.  Order a full pie...whatever you do don't succumb to the single slice.
2.  Feel free and order any of the pastas....all good.
3.  Polenta fries are a go.
4.  Wash it all down with any of the beers they have available.
If you follow any of these, you will have a great meal at Pi Bar.
author: Sheila Y.

description:
Pizza slice was just okay, lacked flavor. And why put the pepper and oregano in a dish instead of a shaker? It doesn't make you look fancier, it just makes it harder to get a normal amount on your pizza.

I asked the waitress about the new Liberty beer on tap,and  if it was bitter. She said it wasn't at all. I said, I don't like bitter.. she said nope, its not bitter at all. 

It was, and I didn't like it. A good waitress would have let me have a taste, we were sitting across from the tap at the bar for craps sake. OR suggested one of the Belgium beers they have on tap now, or anything that wasn't bitter. But she seemed more focused on drinking her own beer and hanging with the other bar tenders than giving decent service too us.

As I was leaving, I noticed the "people hate us on yelp" sign. I laughed, props to them. I appreciate honesty.

but still...
author: Erin A.

description:
Finally made it here. My borther-in-law is always talking about this place. We had my neices 2nd birthday party here and had the place to ourselves. First I love the name. I also love that they open at 3:14 everyday. I know I am nerd but whatever.

The pizza was good. I tried the cheese with basil strips on top. Good flavor but nothing over the top special. 

I fell in love with the polenta fries. OH MY GOD, such heavenly goodness in a little fried polenta stick. It comes with parm on top and a little marinara for dipping. Just thinking about them is making my mouth water and me hungry.

Cute little neighborhood hangout with lots of local beer on tap.  I can't really comment on price since I was at the party and everything was paid for. 

But really go have a beer and some polenta fries!
author: Becca R.

description:
c'mon, everybody wants this place to succeed.  A NYC slice with premium ingredients, who doesn't want that.  And an assortment of beers on tap.  Rainbow cake is good, real fudge.

Well maybe those 2 don't belong together.  Maybe a NY slice should be made at Arinnes, fast, dirty, cheap, and good.

The slice is blah.  Weak on cheese, soggy tips, sauce is forgettable. 

Service is good so I'm sure they don't want to hear foodies tell them how to make their pizza.  But here's a start.

Somebody there get a slice from Escape from NY, Arinells, Extreme Pizza, and Pauline's.  From there, keep working at it until you beat them all.  Paulines will be hardest, so keep making it simple but perfect.
author: J S.

description:
Food:

Solid pizza, which benefited from the liberal addition of Parmesan cheese.  Under no circumstances order the appetizers - you might as well order another large pizza for the price of the mozzarella balls and pizza wheels or whatever they are called.  They didn't taste bad, but were absurdly priced for what you got.

Yay good beer list.  

Service:

Pleasant, accommodating, nothing to complain about.  

Overall, I really don't understand why everyone was salivating for this place to open.  You can get better pie at Arinell's.
author: Kat M.

description:
It's for the best that the pizza here isn't anywhere above average. The crowds generated by a genuine slice of pizza available at an establishment with such a distinguished atmosphere would ruin the appeal.

Everything besides the food gets an A. The beer selection is great and everchanging. The bar itself is gorgeous. The wood-paneled, drinking-in-bruce-waynes-library feel is pretty singular for this side of the city. So what if the only the knock is the pizza is borderline mediocre?. That's fine. I live 2 blocks away and would just assume not having to wade through waves of douche to find a seat and a beer.
author: Henry G.

description:
The rundown for those who don't have time to read an epic novel

-- The pizza (by the slice): Crispy crust, light on sauce, cheesed to perfection w/toppings for just about every craving. I had peperoni but kept picking off my friends sausage masterpiece.

-- The beers: Will put others bars shame. There's something to be said about the stemware they use - it's a solid touch

-- The service: Sitting at the bar was a great way to get introduced to Pi. Enough time to check out every nook & cranny, including chatting up the friendly, knowledgeable staff. I knew I would like this place when I asked for a beer  similar to another and got a recommendation sans attitude (such a rarity). 

-- The layout: Long/wide bar to accommodate your pizza pie & beers; tables for larger groups & kiddies; open kitchen to daydream about the life of a pi-maker. Hooks under the bar for your bags, jackets and anything hang-able. 

-- Overall: It's pizza and beer done in a way that you don't feel like you're reliving your undergrad days. You'll take your friends here and they'll thank you for bringing them to somewhere unpretentious and downright good.
author: Jonathan C.

description: Saturday February 8 was beer week and Pi Bar was pouring Deschutes Brewery's beers. Never been to Pi but was very familiar with Bend brewery Deschutes excellent beers and looking forward to trying a few not normally available. Arrived shortly after 3pm....3.14...how cute,  and was shocked to see a "pour" of 6 ounces priced a $6. That translates to $16 per pint!!!...we left and went to Beer Revolution in Oakland which was hosting a Sierra Nevada tap takeover of 58 taps and priced pints were a very reasonable $6. Won't be back to this place.
author: Mark O.

description: Polenta fries good. Drink a lot before you eat their pizza though--not good!
author: Tiger H.

description:
I really want this place to work.  It looks great from the outside, I love the high rise table in the front window, but the food is hurting.  Big time.  I don't mind paying for good pizza, and this isn't it.  The beer selection is  excellent, which will maybe bring me back in, but I need a better slice!  And for that matter, more/better/bigger cheese for $10.  

Pi Bar also needs to pay attention to the temperature that different beers are supposed to be served. Not all beers want to be ice cold.  Maybe these things have changed since I was last in, but I gave it a few shots in the beginning, and I think i'm done.
author: Emliy H.

description:
I went to Pi Bar last week with friends, wife and baby. We all really enjoyed it!
The pizza was great. We had two pies between about 6 eaters, which was perfect. One was a white pie, the other was housemade Italian sausage. Both were fantastic, and compare very well indeed to NY pizza (I just moved to SF from NYC).
