Great beer selection also - I had a couple I'd never heard of. The space is great - cool high ceiling, long bar, lots of room - there was no problem putting the baby down in her seat on the bench next to us.
For top notch pizza and beer I highly recommend Pi. It's a great addition to the Mission.
author: Killian M.

description: They have a good selection of Micro brews, many that you will not find anywhere else, and they have great pizza. Its a good place to go to on a thursday night if your not looking a for a crowd. Also the girl bartender is really nice!
author: Giselle W.

description: OVerrated. Overpriced. Annoying people. Terrible pizza. Unbelievable attitude for such a tasteless pile of expensive cardboard. I gave it two stars because one star sounds as if I only went here once. Yes, I've gone back and it was just as bad as before. If you believe having a motorcycle makes you cool, you'll meet many people just like yourself here!
author: Georgia D.

description:
Great beer selection, decent wine selection and quality service. We oredered a large sausage pizza, and although the pizza was gigantic, it was dry and kinda tough. We asked for some kind of dipper, but they told us they had none. I cut the inside of my mouth on the dry crust. The flavor was good though.
I got 2 glasses of wine, and my boyfriend got 2 beers and a large pizza was $55. The pizza alone was 25 for a large one topping. Ok, but certainly not worth the price.
author: Emily G.

description:
So, I don't much care for this whole layman review culture, not that I hold our top professionals in high regard. But some of the stuff I read on yelp just makes me mad.

So here I am. This Pi place is making, in my NYC centric mind, the best slice of Pizza in the city. That guy in north beach is doing a pretty good job too. Don't get me started on that Yahoo over on 11th street...

There are plenty of dandy grilled cheese sandwiches in town that natives call pizza. Generally over proofed dough bombs or matzo with tomato puree on top. It that's your style, go eat that stuff. You won't like this, I promise.

I admit I'm prejudiced, but this is the style of pizza I like, and I think they do it very well. If you went to NY and had pizza and thought it was good, you will like this place. Plus the beer selection is top notch.

four stars, Vinnie says, check it out.
author: Statin Island V.

description:
The white pie is de-lish!!  

By the slice-- just OK.

Awesome beer selection.
author: Angela N.

description:
Maybe my expectations were too high but this was not great pizza - so-so at best. I should mention that I did not eat the pizza at Pi Bar but did take out instead. I will give it one more try, eat-in, in a few weeks to make a fair comparison to other Mission pizzerias. For the details of my take-out experience, read on.

First off, their website sucks. It was difficult to find a phone number to call ahead. It should be on every page at the bottom. Their menu doesn't have prices except for a couple of items. Hopefully, both issues will be fixed soon.

When I did find the number to order, they asked whether I wanted small or large. It only took 15 minutes to make and pickup from when I ordered so nothing bad there. Pleasantly, once I got to the restaurant, I found the small is actually a 15" pie. The large is apparently about 25". The small with two ingredients was $21 so priced just a bit more than most local Mission pizzerias, but not overly so.

The restaurant itself looked nice though I didn't spend much time there. Spacious and the tables were not packed together. There's a bar area with stools and the beer selection looked good enough to come back for later. Need to try their 2*Pi*R special with a slice and a beer.

The pizza itself was disappointing. It wasn't terribly warm by the time I got home so I was off to a bad, and maybe unfair, start. The cheese had congealed to the point that I needed a knife to cut a slice off. The crust, though perfectly crunchy on the outer edges, was too thin and soggy in the middle to the point where l had trouble peeling it off the paper. The ingredients were definitely fresh but I wasn't a huge fan of the taste of the cheese.

Overall, I'd say this pizza is a bit better than your random neighborhood pizzeria but definitely not as good as the premier pie places in the Mission (eg, Delfina, Pauline's, etc.). It certainly doesn't compare to good true NY pizzas and is arguably not even as good as Arinell's up the street at 16th and Valencia. It does however get points for having the beer and a great name for a special. I'll try it again and maybe even include it in my regular pizzeria rotation (with lowered expectations), but Pi Bar is nothing special.
author: Anand M.

description:
Great place for Belgium beer lovers. They have several bottled beers and a variety of beers on draft. 

I had a decent IPA on draft and also tried their special of the day which tasted similar to a Pale Ale. 

For $6, you get a slice of pizza and their beer daily beer choice. All their pizzas are organic. They're thin and comparable to NY pizza, but I wouldn't be back for it. 

It's a great hangout spot, and their beer selection will definitely bring me back!
author: crystal e.

description:
Pie a bit dry, sigh
Spinach salad with sausage
Perfect.  Warm, chill, nice.
author: Paula M.

description:
Had a little trouble finding this spot. I didn't know there were restaurants on THIS SIDE of Valencia. Had to walk four blocks in hungry confusion, but eventually found it. 

Beers, servers, and the pizza were all great. I was tempted to order the other appetizers and entrees but it was only the two of us. I came in on a Sunday night and there was enough room for everyone but I can see how this place can be too packed on any other night as noted in the other reviews. 

Would love to see made up creations, instead of picking your own toppings. Indecisive people steer clear!
author: Charlie L.

description: I really liked the crispy crust NY-style pizza. Was nice! I also thought the vibe was cozy. Lots of good beer selections served in all kinds of nice glasses. BUT BUT BUT the prices were WAY WAY WAY TOO HIGH. Our meal for 10 ended up being $270. Whoa. For pizza. Are you kidding me: $10 for mozzarella sticks. We ordered liberally. The garlic pinwheels were also stale-tasting - but looked so good - such a disappointment.
author: Andrew K.

description:
I had dinner and beers here last week and loved it. My friend and I felt very taken care of by one of the owners (Jen?). I love it when bartenders offer beer samples! 

We shared the Bocconcini and Toybox Tomato Salad ($9.00) and a large pizza with sausage, mushrooms and olives. Both were delicious. I had 2 pints of the Tiburon Blonde, which was very good. 

I would love to come here often, but while I'm still unemployed this place is too pricey for me. With a tip our bill was almost $40/person. 

I love the vibe and the food at Pi Bar and it's only a 7 minute walk from my house in Bernal Heights. Valencia Street keeps getting better and better.
author: Yvette K.

description:
I love Pi Bar.

If you are in the neighborhood it is a great place to stop in for a beer. We typically go after work and at that time it is never empty but not over-crowded either. The beer selection is the real star here. They have many rotating choices on tap. The service is always friendly and knowledgeable. 

I have tried most of the food on the menu and these are my favorites:

Polenta Fries - I love the texture of these! Gotta try em.
White Pizza
Bacon Gorgonzola Zeppoli
Bocconcini and Tomato Salad
author: Katherine S.

description: Pliny the younger 2112 SF Beer Week,, crazy crowded for 3 pm but worth it.
author: Chris D.

description:
Not part of the original "crawl" through the mission, but a SF Pizza staple none the less.

This NY-Style pizza kicked Arenell's ass  and the price isn't that much more if you stick with buying-by-the-slice. The crust was complete (no holes) the sauce had flavor and there was ample salt and grease (grease is important to a pizza, particularly NY-style) oozing from the cheese.

So thats it for the pizza review. I actually went on a "Strong Beer Night" during SF's Beer Week.

My BF and I split the flight of Anchor Steam brews and the meat and cheese pairings. The beer was strong... like the hulk or king kong... some tasty. I wasn't a fan of the Humming (too bitter) or the Bock (too sour and very smoky) but I found the Liberty Ale and the get you drunk without knowing it Barleywine delish.

The meatballs were aight but not too impressive whereas the sausages were very tasty.  Salty, fatty, full of flavor.

All in all a good night........ until I went to sleep. I think the bizzar meat and beer flavors combined with my malaria drugs (I just got back from Costa Rica) had a weird chemical reaction. I had the most vivid, intense, nonsensical nightmares ever. 100% not fun. 

Dreams included: 1. My sister ( I am actually an only child) leaving my Dad to die of AIDS (he HIV negative and the healthiest old guy I know) in Vietnam (he has explicitly told me he has no desire to ever travel in Southeast Asia) because they don't take his Health Insurance. [Can we pass healthcare reform yet? Its effecting my dream.} As a result of my dream-induced sister leaving my Dad in Vietnam I kill her. 2. Sara as Will Smith in "I am Legend" except it didn't take place in NYC we were in a Costa Rican jungle. Zombie dogs do not make for a restful night sleep.

Suggestions: Try pretty much anything here, unless you are taking medications that effect your neuro-system as a side effect.
author: Sara K.

description:
Pros: Tasty pizza and salads, fun beer selection.
Cons: Atmosphere not too cozy, fried mozzarella tasted like it was frozen.
author: Tamara M.

description:
I love this place !! not a bad beer on tap(or in bottle) 
the pizza is great too .. and real cheap .. great quality meats on the pie .. and the polenta fries are amazing as well !! 
the owners always chats it up w me and makes me feel comfortable in this neighborhood bar !
author: Micah W.

description:
I'd give Pi Bar a solid 3.14159 rating.

Service was great, pizza slices are huge and taste fine (B-), polenta fries were interesting but not sensational, decor is a bit bleak/cold and the blues being played over the sound system was excellent.  

They open at 3:14 PM - clever.
author: Rick B.

description:
Pizza and Beer is a magical combination, and Pi Bar pulls it off in style.

There is a huge selection of beer including lots of bottles to choose from, and a good number of rotating taps.  If you like Belgian style beer, you'll definitely find something to like.

The warm spinach salad is tasty.  The sausage they put on the pizza is made in house and probably my favorite topping here.
author: Chris K.

description:
Pi Bar fills a nice niche in the neighborhood ... a place where you can sit down, relax and order a whole pie and choose between constantly changing local beers on draft.  Or alternatively, you can order by the slice to go if you're in a hurry.

Since we weren't in a rush, we chose the former route.  Right off the bat, two things impressed me: first, the local selection of beers on tap (as it was one of those rare, warm SF days, we preferred the light, clean Alaskan summer to the somewhat hoppy and fruity Mt. Shasta lager) and second, there was NO WAIT at all for a 6:30 dinner! (it did start getting crowded by the time we left, however).

Not being particularly hungry, we split a small tomato pie w/ italian sausage and roasted peppers (which is plenty for two people, with leftovers).  The pizza was pretty good - really thin and not too crispy.  The toppings were excellent.  I don't know if the pie ranks as high as some of the other pizzas in the city (A16, Beretta, Gialina, Flour & Water) but if you're not in the mood to wait for hours to get seated, this is a great alternative.

Finally, the service was excellent.  I especially liked our waitress, who was really friendly and attentive but wasn't one of those "hoverers".  Her style fits perfectly with the casual vibe of the place.
author: F. P.

description:
The beer selecetion is great, the ambiance is good but I was hoping for good pizza, too, and it was only edible. Basically a nice beer bar that also serves some edible food.

Drinking the Alaska Smoked Porter right now, it's like drinking a campfire :D.
author: Evan M.

description:
My roommate and I headed here on a Tuesday evening for pizza and beer.  Upon arrival we were immediately seated at the bar, and the pleasant (but not overly friendly) gal behind the bar patiently answered our questions about the beers.  They have a nice selection, and I liked my Alleycat Amber just fine, though my roomie wasn't so fond of the raspberry lambic.

We went simple and ordered a plain cheese and tomato sauce pie.  My roommate got a side of meatballs.  The pizza was fine.  I liked the taste of the crust, but wasn't too fond of the general sweet/anise-y pizza aftertaste.  The cheese reminded my roommate of "school lunch pizza."  The meatballs were tasty, and rather crumbly.  Again, fine.

Though there weren't many people there (the bar was pretty full and there were a couple folks at the community table) it was quite loud.

Overall, a pleasant enough experience, but nothing special or stand-out.  I'd consider returning, but I'm also not in any rush.
author: Pam M.

description:
They have Blind Pig IPA and friendly service. Good enough for me!
(In addition, they actually keep the music level at a reasonable level)
I'll be back....
author: KEVIN M.

description:
Great beer selection, nice lighting and delicious balsamic onion pizza (nice and salty with sweet undertones).

Why three stars you ask?  Overpriced, a little lack of atmosphere and skimpy on the polenta fries.
author: Liz B.

description: I would like to make Pi Bar my go-to bar.  I can't believe I had never been here!  The pizza looked delicious, but we had just come from gorging ourselves at Straw, and thus could not partake in the pizza eating festivities.  Next time FOR SURE though.
author: Nora S.

description:
On the plus side: Service is really, really nice. Good beer selection, good music, and a few doors down from where I live.

On the minus side: the pizza:

1) Burnt crust (and I've been there twice now)
2) Crust not too tasty (the outer crust was hard an inedible to me)
3) Almost no sauce on the pizza.

I want to love this place but the pizza is meh. Arinelles is a NY style tastier pie, no doubt, and cheaper (though lacking in ambience).

I will no doubt go back at some point due to the proximity of the place, and if they get the pizza right, I'll bump up their stars. But for me, this is still 2.5-3 stars.
author: sam p.

description:
Pi Bar is a nice addition to the neighborhood. I joined a group of friends here for a farewell gathering. The gang had settled in early so seating was not an issue. Pi Bar is almost unrecognizable from its previous days as Suriya, nice pressed tin ceiling. 

The small pizzas are quite large but they have a thin crust so you can still put away a few slices. Pi Bar is also open to half and half topping combos to maximize tasting opportunities. Our first pie had portabellos and balsalmic onions for the veggies and our second had bacon and parm. It takes a rather bold vegetarian pizza to tear my attention away from a bacon pie, but the mushroom and onion pie was quite tasty. We followed up with a roasted peppers and parm all around, anchovies on half. The crust was thin enough to not feel doughy but with a good chew. All in all, I was quite happy with the pizza and will add it to the neighborhood take-out rotation. If only they delivered!

I found the sparkling and white wines to be lacking but I guess the draw here is the beer selection. Still, perfectly content to have found a place where I can have a few drinks and some pizza with friends in the neighborhood. 3.5 stars.
author: Candice L.

description: I came here last night for SF Beer Week with the boyfriend and a friend of ours.  We were pleasantly surprised by this place.  It wasn't as divey as we were expecting, but it also wasn't douchey either.  It was the good comfortable mix that made us feel relaxed and not out of place.  The boyfriend enjoyed his beers (I was DD and had the ginger ale, which I actually wasn't that impressed with, get better ginger ale/beer.) and we ordered a pizza and while it wasn't the best pizza in the world, it certainly hit the spot and was exactly what was needed.
author: Quynh-An P.

description:
While so much of what makes Pi Bar fabulous has already been said, there are two salient points still to be made:

1) Their white pizza is perfect.  So many places out here make a white pie with some sort of cream sauce concoction.  That does not a white pie make.   Theirs is perfect. 

2) They are the only place in the city that has rainbow cookies.  Even if that doesn't mean anything to you, you should be excited. 

One star off for the ambiance and logistics. The tables weren't set up in a way conducive to... well, anything... and we were asked to move three times.  Total bummer.   It was an SF Beer Week night, so I can deal with the large crowd and the wait-staff forgetting to refill my water -- but having tables set up so that people can't actually eat their meal?    Bummer.
author: Nora B.

description:
Visited Pi yesterday afternoon for a late lunch with 2 friends.  We ordered a few beers, and a large pizza (half with anchovies & olives, and the other half with meatballs).  Pretty good.  The anchovies were fresh and delicious...apparently they cure them themselves.  The meatballs were smaller than expected, but yummy.  Nice beer selection.  I would visit them again, if ever in the Mission craving some pizza.  (Note, they also sell pizza by the slice.)

Also, beers were $3.14 (hence Pi).

Cheers!
author: Brian V.

description:
* Name/Sign - 4 stars (awesome, mathematic, nerdy)
* Beer Selection - 4 stars (varied but nothing amazing)
* Service - 3 stars (friendly but not the most attentive service I've ever had, especially considering there weren't that many people in there on Thursday evening)
* Pizza - 3 stars (tasty when I was hungry, but after my third slice I had no inclination to eat more.  Sauce was a little sweet, cheese was a little bland, toppings were good but not spectacular).

A side of something would probably give me a slightly better idea of what this place is like across the board.  While I appreciated their no-nonsense approach to pizza (get a plain, you figure out the toppings), I feel like the menu was a little sparse, and it was kind of loud for a place that seems like it is trying to be a little more of a restaurant then a bar. $20 a large pie seems a little high to me too.

Maybe one day I'll eat here again and want to bump their score up to a 4, instead of rounding down to a 3.  However, I'll probably never suggest this place as one to get pickup from if we just want some pizza, and since pizza is what they are going for, they will be a 3 for now.
author: Tmon B.

description: Good beer selection, but the bartenders are just awful. We went to Pi Bar with a group of about 20 laid back people - ordered plenty of drinks, food, and were having a good time. Then, the bartenders - some bearded guy and attitudey chick - flip out about how we have too many tabs open. Then, they lose a friend's credit card and act like it's his fault. Please. If customers are annoying, find a different job - maybe a photo developer in a darkroom or something.
author: Danny G.

description: I really want to like this place.  The bar is nice and the beers are good.  But if  a place is going to tie its fortune to pizza and beer, the pizza better be really good, and in this case it just isn't.  I agree with the Girlish M. review here.  Who cares about organic this and that if it doesn't actually taste good.  The crust just does not cut it, i's like bread rather than crust, and too dense.  The cheese and red sauce are just meh.  It is not that hard to make a nice pie.  If they could figure that out, the place would be jumpin.  Til then, there are loads of better options.
author: Ruth F.

description:
Hooray for a crispy crust and a great selection of beers!
No attitude neighborhood place.
author: K S.

description:
We walked in at 8:30 on a Saturday and were seated with beers in minutes.  The other two places we tried to go -- Pizetta 211 and Flour + Water -- weren't seating anyone else that night.

The beer list is fantastic (try the North Coast Pranqster), the pizza is great (get the meatballs), and the service is excellent.  

It's a little more expensive than I expected, and a little louder than I would like, but I can live with both those things.

Unpretentious, high-quality pizza and beer.  Love it.
author: evan m.

description:
Overall, good beer selection and bartender but average pizza.

Pitched up here on a friday night around 7:45 and popped our names onto the waiting list. It was around 10 people deep and those near the top had been waiting 40 mins already. We dived out and hit the Attic around the corner and back back 45 mins later to find that we were 1 off from the top of the list. Took an additional 30mins to get seated as the servers were a little disorganized.

Beer selection was great, as was the bar tender We finally got seated and ordered a large pie with peppers, sausage and onions. It turned up 10 mins later minus the onions (but with double peppers?). Pizza itself was ok - crust was very thin but the cheese selection wasn't perfect. The crust was ciabatta like, which was a little odd and sadly it was fairly burnt on the bottom.

We'd probably only come back to the bar for the tasty beer selection.
author: Nick L.

description:
They have beer and they have pizza.   I'm neither a beer drinker nor a pizza eater.  I'll have a beer if it is really hot and I'll eat pizza if it is really amazing and I'm starving.   And I'll eat a salad any day of the week and usually do. 

I have to say, this is a good place for a group to hang out, have some beers, chat and have some food.   The staff was good - timely, knowledgeable about beer (from what I know) and  worked fine with our group. Not over the top friendly or anything, but there was no ignoring or MIA service like some mentioned below.

There were a lot of different kinds of beer.   The salad dressing was too much for the salad (typical of salad in a pizza place, that's what you get for ordering salad at a pizza place.)  We had a group and ordered a few pizzas to share.   I took a slice, ate the first bite off the end, and handed the remainder to my bf and told him I'd be fine just eating the crust - I only have 2000 calories per day and if I'm going to spend them on pizza, it has to be exceptional.
author: Maria C.

description:
Overpriced pizza that doesn't taste very good.  Service is ok.  The owner has that "customers are just so annoying" attitude that makes me not want to spend my money there.  I can get good beers somewhere else, where they actually want my business.
Go to Little Star instead.
author: Danielle T.

description:
I really like this pizza & beer joint.  I've came here a couple times after work for my happy hour.  It has a great selection of local beers and the pizzas are HUGE.  Their warm spinach salad was very tasty and polenta fries were awesome.

I'd say its more of a restaurant then a bar - at least on a Friday night.  After being there for 3 - 4 hours, enjoying our beer and pizza, I felt like the dinner crowd wanted us to leave and free up a table.  Its definitely not a place to just hang out and relax for hours on end on a weekend night but its still a great place to enjoy great beer and great pizza.
author: Bianca R.

description:
Very tasty pizza - thin and flavorful.

Good beer on tap - Anchor's Liberty

Quick and simple
author: Brian S.

description: It's pretty simple.  If you don't like Pi Bar, there's a good chance I wouldn't want to hang out with you.  Awesome pizza, awesome beer, awesome space.  Seriously, it's good.  Go there.  Easiest Yelp review ever.
author: Sean H.

description:
My neighborhood pizza joint is extremely convenient in it's menu and size option for pizza, if we want a small pizza or a party pizza.  It doesn't get any simple than that.

Menu is expanding to pasta of the day and sandwich items.  GREAT salad and even though I am not partial to anchovies, I respect that they brine their own daily.  

Pi Bar I heart you.
author: Michael C.

description:
Great pizza.  I find the Chicago/New York style pizza debate tedious.  Both done well are superb.  Both done poorly suck.  I went to college in Chicago and can say that not all the pizza I had there was as good as Little Star here in SF.  Same with New York insofar as it relates to Pi.  Very good pizza.  Superb beer.  You can buy by the slice or get a whole pie.  

Would I go back?  Absolutely.
author: Sam P.

description:
Not a bad place to go to. The first time I was here, the wait was so long that my boyfriend and I left. It's big, yet there isn't enough sitting (yet, I can't quite figure out how they can fit more).

The pizza is reasonably priced, the beer as well, and though it wasn't the worst slice I've had, it certainly wasn't the best either. But overall, something made our stay quite pleasant. Maybe it was the beer.

It kinda throws me off that they don't really have a hostess.
author: Alexia R.

description: $42 two topping large? it was just super greasy and soggy
author: Matthew R.

description:
I went here last night, and I have to say, a pretty decent experience.  I really wanted this to be a 4-star place, but alas I can only give three stars.  
We had a large pizza, with meatballs and roasted peppers.  Now I have to say, I would have gone for feta and olives, but my traditional east coast boyfriend would have nothing to do with those types of "weird fusion california toppings."  We went traditional, and let me say, the meatballs were great.  The roasted peppers decent as well.  Maybe I would have been happier if we had gotten a half-and-half pizza-- perfect for all those indecisive people like me!  So overall, the pizza was good, but not as good as I was hoping it to be.  

Besides the okay pizza, let me say that the beer is great.  I had a great belgian beer that I was pretty obsessed with.  So many options, and the waiters/waitress are very knowledgeable about the beers on tap.
The service was also great.

Overall, i say check this place out, and get a few different types of pizza/toppings so you are sure to get one fabulous one.
author: Sarah B.

description:
I had to bump it up to 5, cause now we have started making a weekly visit to Pi bar to have yummy food and beer.  My husband always goes for pizza, and I always go for pasta.  Its all a perfect compliment to the beers they have on tap.  They also have a Toronado-worthy selection of Belgian beers in bottles.  Splurge on a Cinq Cents if you are feeling fancy.

My preference is for the bar, but we have sat at the big table up front as well.  I love the room and the staff are charming.  If we plan our evening right, we can get there for the happy hour beer-and-a-slice special, then run over to Anthony's Cookies for yummy cookies to bring back.  Kind of a perfect night, actually.

I really appreciate the simplicity of their menu, and the stunning freshness of the food.  Its a lovely addition to the neighborhood.
author: Liz R.

description: A mass exodus of hipsters and hippies in the Mission to the playa can only mean one thing:  it's finally time to venture out and try all of those overly crowded restaurants with long waits.  Pi being no exception, we were stunned to see no line and were immediately seated.  The white pizza is divine.  Much better quality and quantity than Delfina.  Service was great too. We will be back for the beer.
author: Megha S.

description:
What can I say - love it. friendly service, awesome foodie food and beer, and no TVs to wail awhile the community.

Go, eat, and be merry!
author: Ryan D.

description:
They gotta get their pizza prices in line with reality. There's some serious competition for pizza in SF.   One thing I did like was the general setup of the place. Casual, beer and wine.

Pi Bar, I hope you get better!
author: Daniel W.

description:
Anytime a friend is in town, I take them here, I'd say that's pretty good. I'm used to NY style thin crust pizza, since I just moved here from NJ, and this place satisfy my need for great pizza. I love any pizza with pesto, and by the slice or by the pie, this place is pretty fast.

They have a great beer selection on tap light to dark, and they always have at least one cider on tap. I'm particularly partial to the organic pomegranate cider. The guys and gals who work here know their beers and are really great at making suggestions for those less savvy. Their menu for bottled beers also seems pretty extensive, but I always prefer beers on tap to bottles, so I haven't really looked in detail at what they offer. 

The atmosphere is great, laid-back, and chill, perfect for a neighborhood bar, and perfectly located ridiculously close to me.
author: Stephanie C.

description: It was mediocre pizza w a good choice of beers. Decent place. =)
author: Genaro R.

description:
I remember my first time in NYC, everyone said I had to try the pizza. What I found was that I loved the thin crispy crust, but being a West-coaster I wasnt impressed with the canned, frozen, rarely fresh toppings, not to mention having to use a pile of napkins to mop up the greasy oil slick floating on the top of my pie - if you dont think that got me dirty looks from the natives ;)
but, I digress...
I have now visited Pi 3 times and am craving a housemade sausage portobello mushroom slice just thinking about it!   Pi is a bi-coastal marriage made in pizza heaven!  My favorite thing is that you get that wonderful "New York Style" crust made with a variety of fresh, local, ingredients (organic and sustainable when available) - they also feature local wines, craft beers and soft drinks.  

They have a great selection of toppings which you can pick and choose to build your custom combo. The meats are top notch as are the veggies... the roasted peppers are so yummy and I dont know what they do to the onions, but they are carmelized to perfection. The sausage and mushroom is my fave... For you special needs types - My housemate has allergies, dairy, vinegar, sulfites... He has to be really picky about ingredients, and no big surprise he went to Pi and they were happy to build him a pizza to meet his dietary needs.  

I really cant say enough about the staff, they are so incredibly friendly and knowledgeable, they are happy to answer questions and are never too busy to chat and make you feel like they really care and are glad you came. Shout out to James and Jen, bartenders extraordinaire! 

I am not much of a beer drinker, but I know enough to know what I like and dont like. They are more than patient, they seem genuinely happy to let me try 2, 3, even 4 beers before making my selection. I want to try some just for the funny names, like HeBrew JEWbilation and Speakeasy's prohibition beer. Last night, after 3 tastes I opted for the Blind Pig IPA - YUM! 

I try to stay away from the big chains and support the small local businesses whenever possible. I love that Pi supports the local community in their food and beveraging sourcing, so not only do I get to support a local business but I also get to support many of their local suppliers. 

As for the décor, its dark woodsy feel is very relaxing and casual. The music can be a bit loud, but not so loud that you cant carry on a conversation, plus I like the bluesy tracks so turn it up!  Oh, but the best part is that it is walking distance! I have found my "Cheers!"

Lastly, I just have to respond to some of the criticisms from my fellow yelpers, like the fact that they don't carry imports on draft... can you see how that doesn't fit with the local sourcing concept? You can get an imported beer anywhere, and while I have much love and respect for my fellow reviewers, I have to respectfully dissent on that point.  I don't think that is necessarily a bad thing and certainly don't feel the lack of imports on draft merits a star deduction. Again, local business means local jobs and that local money stays in the community.

The same goes for the pricing issue... true, the pizza is not cheap, but neither are organic, local and fresh ingredients.  So while it may be slightly more than your average pizza, I am willing to pay a few bucks more for local ingredients and to support my community. Plus, if you are on a budget you can check out the daily Pi "R" Square Special - A Single Slice and Beer of the Day is only $6.28!

Ok, I'll get off my pizza box now, and perhaps walk down for that slice I'm a cravin'...
author: Yolanda I.

description:
You definitely have to time showing up to this place: around 7:30 on a Thurs/Fri, this place is packed and it -will- take you an hour or more to be seated. At 9pm, this place was a ghost town. Fortunately, you can drown your wait with an excellent high-alcohol content microbrew - heck, I may even go here before other restaurants for their extensive selection.

The pizza was really good - ginormous slices, although watch your toppings - if you're not careful, it it really easy to create a $37 pizza. Seriously.
author: Andy T.

description: If I could give zero stars I would. You two girls know who you are. I came tonight on vacay with my mom n fam. If we made a mistake just kindly tell us and we can find a solution together. Instead staff there were hella passive aggressive rude and just needed the balls to politely tell us wassup. Either way I'm sorry for u guys cause u messed up tell us we were a fire hazard tell us we were in the way tell us something don't make it like it was our decision to stay because obviously it wasn't. Message to owner I'm sure ur restaurant is great but ur servers have an attitude. Then when my mom spoke to them, they talked back. Wtf kind of service is that?!  I only wish that u guys fix things cause horrible horrible horrible worst first impression. And yes I will tell all of my friends.
author: Puwett V.

description: Living in San Jose, I wish we had more bars like this down here. I came to Pi Bar twice this past week because they were sampling two of my favorite breweries, Anderson Valley and Russian River, for SF beer week. I really enjoyed this place's style, before we arrived I was expecting an alright pizza place serving great beer. The place is a little small and doesn't have to much seating but we were able to find a spot at the bar. It took a while to grab the bartender's attention because they were really busy, but once we did they seemed to be really friendly and got us our beers quick. The beers were excellent, poured perfectly and not too overpriced. We decided to check out a menu and ended up ordering slices of sausage and bacon pizza. I was shock when it arrived, I love thin crust New York style pizza and these guys know what's up. The topping on the pizza were also awesome, real thick slices of bacon, and it complemented the beer really well. I will make this a must go to spot every time I'm in the city because it's really that great.
author: Joey K.

description:
"I love this pizza!"  I actually said this out loud while enjoying a small sausage pizza and a Black Cherry soda with my wife.

I really like pizza, and for quite a while I have been convinced that Little Star made the best pizza in San Francisco -- then Micheal Bauer and all of my neighbors convinced me that Gialina makes the best.

Those are both good pizzas, but different then Pi Bar.  While Little Star is deep dish, and Gialina is more Italian in nature, Pi Bar is New York styled pizza and it is delicious.

We ordered a large to go pizza a little over a week ago with meatballs and onions and it was terrific.  The perfect combination of crispy crust and gooey cheesiness.  My only complaint was their ridiculously over sized pizza box.  I thought I was going to have to strap it on the hood of my car to get it home.

Yesterday on our visit, we ordered a small sausage pizza and pinwheels to start.  Their sauce is very good and it was really highlighted with the Pinwheels.  ext to arrive was our small pizza  -- plenty big enough for the 2 of us to get our fill and still have left overs for today.  Again delicious.

Now for the price, I have no complaints about the pricing here.  2 sodas, a small pizza and a starter and we got out of there for $35.  Not exactly cheap, but this is San Francisco and you will pay that much or more at many other pizza joints so I think the pricing is more than fair.

All in all, I have decided that this will be my new go to pizza place.  They done an outstanding job and I am really looking forward to what (if any) new offerings they add to the menu.
author: Tom Y.

description:
Good solid NY style pizza & good bears on tap = what more could one ask for?!

Pi does serve other stuff (some apps, pasta dishes) but unsure if the other stuff is good since we just ordered a pie.  

I'd totally go back and order a large pizza with cheese and some beers.  Yummy.
author: Carol S.

description: My husband and I love this place! It was our favorite place for a dinner date in the neighborhood before our daughter was born and now that she is a toddler, we are happy that we still feel welcome back. There aren't many places in the city that are family friendly and that we also would opt to go to on a date night out. We don't feel doomed to dine at cheesy restaurants just because we have a baby. The staff is friendly, the service is great and the food, beer and wine are top notch. Highly recommend!
author: Brooke B.

description:
Pi Bar rocks! Really top notch beer selections and delicious pizza from all local ingredients - nothing from a can! Their homemade meatballs and anchovies are particularly delicious. The crust is great too. All very reasonably priced.

Another plus is that they're very kid friendly. Where else can you go and enjoy a beer selection like this with kids in tow? Staff is very friendly and helpful too.

I honestly don't know what some of the other folks who panned this place are thinking. Snobs? Who knows, who cares, more beer and pie for us! I'm so happy to have this place in the neighborhood.
author: Sebastian T.

description:
Great pizza. Celiac friendly cider for wifey.

They have a painting of my Moto Guzzi (Owner insists it's his, but I know better). 

I think this will get better with time, plainly styled and brightly lit, needs the SF break-in period.
author: Freud R.

description: This place is near my apartment and I love everything about it. Always great beer and the pizza is so delicious (my favorite topping is the mixed bell peppers). The staff is really friendly and always has beer recommendations. The salads, baked ziti and fried mozzerella are also worth trying. Can get crowded on Friday and Saturday nights. Happy hour with $3.14 slices is a great idea too.
author: Emma S.

description: Good food at a great price; this place has a fantastic beer list and real "neighborhood" atmosphere. Definitely will be coming back to Pi Bar!
author: Rebecca A.

description:
I'm delighted at the pizzaria.  Had a very nice dinner here with a couple friends.  The pizza was very good and a good value.  Though the pricing structure makes toppings a bit expensive.  They had a nice selection of beers and good decor.  Very comfortable atmosphere.

I'm really looking forward to coming back and just eating a slice at the bar.
author: Mason C.

description:
Wish I could give 3.5 stars. I like it - there's nothing wrong with it - it's just that in a town obsessed with pizza, I feel like the pizza has to be over the top to get higher ratings! I appreciate the super casual neighborhood feel. Great beers on tap (Death and Taxes) and a long first come first serve bar. 

I also get that they're not trying to compete with the Delfinas or Berettas of the city. It seemed like the NYC slice was more the model here. The pies were large, the pick-your-own-toppings were relatively traditional, and they actually serve oregano along with the chili flakes! The pizza was more of an in between, however. Thinner crust and less cheese than the classic NY pie which left me neither here nor there. Again, solid neighborhood spot, just not a huge wow. The spinach salad with sausage was great and the spaghetti down the bar looked good and homey too.

Note: It gets really loud in there when crowded which seems to be most of the time.
author: Crissy G.

description:
The bad
- Service was lacking.  We waited 15 min for a menu, no one checked in with us after we were served our food and it took a good 10 min to track down glass of water, we pulled out our credit card and put it on the table as a sign that we were ready for the check and they picked it up and ran it with out giving us the bill.
- Pizza was OK and lacking in flavor - For the price and the hype my expectations were a bit higher
- The topping options are limited and hard to pair.  For example we eyed the fresh anchovies but there wasn't a good pairing on the vegetable list.
- Even tho this place is further down the Valencia corridor the parking can still be tough

The good
- Great beer list!
- They use local ingredients
- You can get pizza by the slice
- The atmosphere is sophisticated for a pizza place but is still kid friendly


Glad we tried it, but we probably won't go back unless we had out of town guests with kids who were looking for a place close by for a pizza dinner.
author: Jinenne S.

description: Cheap pizza in the Mission that you don't have to be drunk to eat.
author: Bibi M.

description:
We went into Pi Bar the other night, an hour before our reservations at Yo's Sushi Club, to take the 'edge' off of our hunger.  We had been meaning to stop in months before, but their 3:14pm opening time doesn't usually agree with our kidlet's normal naptime.  

We opted for the Pi "R" Square special of a slice of cheese pizza and the beer of the day, a Black Diamond Brewing Company Belgian-styled white ale...all for $6.28.  How can you go wrong?

Pi Bar uses local ingredients to put together their rendition of a classic NY-style pizza.  While my only NY-style pizza comparison is Grimaldi's in Brooklyn, I don't think I can make a fair comparison at this time.  The main difference is that we didn't get a whole pie and didn't have it piping hot and fresh from the oven.  Slices tend to be re-heated upon order.  I can say that I did enjoy the crust.  We were told by Richie, one of the owners, that they had tried different types of flour until they felt that they had perfected it.  I gotta say it was perfect.  Who says you have to use 00 or 0 imported flour?  It was light and thin, no doughy texture, and crispy, but not burnt.  The sauce was not overpowering and complemented the crust with just the right amount spread over it.  The cheese balanced it all out, so that not one flavor stood out over the other.  It wasn't a super NY size slice, but it was satisfying for the 2 of us for a snack.   Actually, we thought it was sooooo good that we ended up ordering a 2nd slice with their homemade sausage on top...which was equally good.  

Richie offered us a taste of Concentrated Evil (or was it Certified Evil), a dark brew collaboration from Lucky Bucket in Truckee, which they have on tap as a special.  Not being the dark brew fan, I wasn't sure that I'd like it.  It actually turned out to be quite nice and didn't have any bitter aftertaste that I was expecting from a dark.  

Typical of many SF pizza aficionados, everyone has their favorite style and their favorite place to go for a pie.  So true to Yelp form,  you're going to hear why this place is good or isn't, because it's not like this place or that place.  Being the melting pot that the City is, I think there's plenty of room for another place that serves NY-style pizza.  I like them all, so I don't play favorites...just depends on what I want at that time.  If your idea of pizza is Delfina or A16, then this isn't your type of pizza...it's NY, not Neapolitan.  If you like Little Star or Patxi's, then you've stepped into the wrong joint...fork and knife not required.  It's not a Victor's or Nizario's type of place either.   You could compare Pi Bar to Arinell's, but the difference would be you get the following at Pi Bar: 1. alcohol, 2. fresh local ingredients, 3. a nice pleasant and warm atmosphere to hang out with friends, family, kids, and 4. no attitude served up with each slice.  Pi Bar just happens to be a bar that serves great NY-style pizza the way it's meant to only be topped...with 1-2 toppings.  And where else are you going to get a great selection of micro-brews to go along with your pie?  No where but Pi Bar.
author: JeFF T.

description: 5 stars!  I love this place.  I think this is the best pizza in the city.  I use to be an Arinells fan but the fact that you can eat in, order other tasty treats and beer it's hard to go anywhere else for pizza.
author: Sandy L.

description: in preparation for passover, I am trying to max out on my non-passover foods in short shrift. Friday night, pizza was the order and I was not disappointed! Now, I am from NY and so am picky about the "pizza" I will eat here in CA. I use the quote because some of this s*** on a shingle people call pizza is a total joke. I would not call this pizza here at Pi the absolute greatest of all time, but it is most definitely a hell of a lot better than most I have had in SF, so there. Also, they get extra bonus almond-paste flavored stars for having perhaps the finest exhibit of NY Italian goodies and that would be rainbow cookies. If you don't know what they are, look them up on wikipedia and then head STRAIGHT to Pi for the tastiest rainbow cookies - I think even better than Rocco's on Bleecker Street in the Village. so there, again! Co-owner is from Bayside (Queens in the HOUSE!) so extra points there for authenticity. Fab beer, a housemade sausage topper made by a bar mitzvahed guy from Queens less than 10 minutes from my house? Can I get an "Amen" up in here? AMEN!
author: Holly C.

description: Pi Bar, I'm done with you.  I have been to your place not less than 20 times since you opened.  I like the pizza and I love the salads but the attitude of the staff and the owners is just plain stupid.  Do you want to keep people away?  Maybe your are busy or maybe I am just not cool enough for you.  Whatever.  You suck - from your asshat owner telling me how much of an inconvenience it would be to bring my friends there for my birthday to the bartender who instead of giving me a check when I asked for it waited on a couple of other people and then went and had a beer at the other end of the bar.  And the woman owner, would it kill you to pull the telephone pole out of your ass and smile once in a while?  I just want to have a pizza and a beer, but clearly that is too much trouble.  Maybe if I rode a motorcycle or I was in the "biz" you'd like me better?  Best of luck to you, I mean it, you need it.
author: Erin M.

description: A rotating draught beer selection here keeps things interesting. The pizza itself, is pretty bleh. Nothing really stood out and it seems like they are trying to overcompensate for the quality of the pizza itself with a large amount of not-very-high-quality toppings.
author: Louis A.

description: Friendly service, better food than you would ever expect to find in a bar (pizza, polenta fries and more - all delicious) and one of the best beer selections to be found in the city make Pi Bar a regular stop for me. Come in, experiment with the beer list offerings (with the input of the helpful and knowledgable bartenders) and enjoy a slice of NY style pizza.
author: Lindsay J.

description:
Pi Bar is the best place to get pizza and beer. 
Really fresh and tasty ingredients and a deep rotating beer selection.
Their pretzels, salads and lasagna are killer too.
author: Nick B.

description:
Great pizza with a crispy thin crust, awesome beer list, other tasty menu gems and friendly staff. More than a pizza-by-the-slice or another bar. Solid 4 stars, the 5th is based on personal taste and a bit speculative.  I love having this place in my neighborhood. 

I've eaten here several times now as it is delicious and very close to my home. I've heard people compare the pizza to Arnell's which I can understand but Pi is of much higher quality. I like Arnells but the pizza is so greasy and lopsided it's a bit of an insult to the dish. Pi uses better ingredients and I think it really comes through. Also the crust is crisper. I realize that pizza tastes vary and I won't waste the time or ASCII characters telling you why I think the pizza is solid and there's more to this place. I will say that like every other pizza blowhard, I've lived in a pizza capital and eaten it more than any other food by far but maybe you're one of those people that likes gooey thick doughy crust and you'd hate this pizza. 

My favorite dish, besides the pizza, is the spinach salad. I hate spinach but you know what, it's good for me. The thing that makes the spinach salad the furthest thing from a pile of bitter leaves is a touch of feta and a few crumbs of Italian sausage heated in the dressing.  Yum!!

During my last visit, I found out that the reason I love the sausage so much may be because it is handmade, on-site, every day! Think Arnells does that? 

Okay, the beer. I like beer. I made my own beer for a few years and I love a place that has a wide variety of beers on tap without being over-the-top beer snobs (I'm looking at you, Toranado). Perennial favorites are on tap as well as a revolving selection of special treats that you won't see in many places.

Honestly I would normally give this place 4 stars because some items on the menu are a buck or two above a great deal.  The thing that pushes it to 5 for me is the math and motorcycle theme of the place. The happy hour special, called the pi*R^2 is a specific beer (different one every day) and a slice of cheese pizza for 6.28. Obviously they are assuming R to be equal to the square root of two and I would call it the 2*pi*R as the common assumption would be that we're talking about the unit circle, but I digress. Also, as is typical for a new restaurant, the menu is going through some changes. I wasn't a big fan of the pinwheels (I learned I just don't like pinwheels) but I hear a meatball sandwich is coming and I really cannot wait. 

One of the owners is a motorcycle buff and has a couple cool pieces of motorcycle artwork on the wall. Also, as mentioned before, the staff is super friendly.
author: Rob I.

description:
Well, we ordered the white sauce pizza with italian sausage and mushrooms and it was pretty blah in the taste department.
 
Maybe a white sauce pizza needs a thinner crust? Maybe I personally just didn't like the white sauce? Who knows...

But I did like our waitress and I liked my wine and I like the fact that there are more items on the menu I want to try. So, I'll give this place another shot, maybe it will impress me next time.
author: A K.

description: HUGE portion sizes.  Oh my god, we each ate what could be defined as a butt load of pizza.   Decent prices, considering how big the pizza is... but... not that tasty... limp wet crust... bland cheese... eh, just didn't really enjoy it.  Don't get me wrong, I still ate it, but didn't really enjoy it.
author: Mon K.

description: consistent use of the mathematical symbol, pi - you see it in their happy hour times, their prices, kinda kitchy...but above and beyond staying on message, a solid bar. what really took this over the top was their solid pizza. i had a few beers and then impulse took over and had a large cheese pie (yes, i know) to go...very good, thin crust. i'm no fanatic about crusts but this pizza was done very well. look, it's not meant to be a fancy bar with artisanal drinks but this is a SOLID bar, they had great beer selection and it was clean, the real bonus was the food.
author: Mayur A.

description: I love when i jot down little things to make sure to put in my yelp reviews.  The thing I wrote for Pi bar was "Limp pepperoni. Bad sauce, good toppings."  I thought that the pizza was ok... I don't know if I will go back here though.
author: Laura P.

description: I came here with some friends to wind up a night in the Mission. Since we had already eaten we did not have a chance to eat pizza though from what I saw it looks amazing. This space looks like it has some years on it, sort of like walking into a nice clean old saloon. They have a kitchen area which is exposed to the dining and bar area. The saloon style bar has a number of tasty beers on tap and a refrigerator with some belgian options to choose from. This seems like a solid beer and pizza option. Not too crowded on a friday night.
author: Eric G.

description: Beer and pizza are delicious.  Overall a bit pricey but at least the portions are pretty generous.  Depending on who is working, the staff is ok.  I think it's a great option if you are looking to expand outside of your usual bar scene.  They take Amex too!
author: K W.

description: I love Pi so much.  And I love it even more now that I've finally tried their Rainbow Cookies.  I don't know what I was expecting, but these things are more like morsels of cake than typical cookies.  Delicious!
author: Christine M.

description: It's a pretty nice atmosphere and the pizza is pretty good.  I would give this place a 3.5 star until I got the check.  Not because it was expensive, but because of the overcharge that the owner/manger was unwilling to take off for the server's mistake.  It's not the money ($8), it's the principal of it.  At the end of the day, I paid the bill and told them that they lost a customer.  The attitude of the manager/owner was pretty unbelievable which is why I am writing this review.  Even if this was the best pizza in the world (which its definitely not), I would never go back and would never recommend this place to any of my friends.
author: Don T.

description: Good pizza. nice selection of beer. try their sour beers (they have 2). so good! don't expect to be seated quickly though, as there are not too many seats. don't believe the other bad reviews about this place - definitely worth a try!
author: Ian C.

description:
Calling all Italian Rainbow Cookie lovers!  My five star rating is based on the amazing Italian Rainbow Cookies, flag cookies, venetian cookies, Italian tri colore cookies, Italian wedding cookies, whatever you wanna call them and the fabulously friendly bartender!  

After failing miserably in my endeavor to find rainbow cookies between San Diego and Los Angeles (FYI if you're ever in Las Vegas, they have amazing rainbow cookies at Tintoretto's in the Venetian.  Make sure you call first to see if they're in stock because they sell out early in the day!), I knew I was destined to find something in San Francisco.  After much google searching, I found an article that mentioned rainbow cookies at Pi.  After braving the rain on my drive to San Francisco, I dragged my best friend out of her cozy condo on Geary in search of these cookies.  When I walked in, I asked for the cookies and felt part of some secret club where you have to say a password to be let in.  After telling the bartender (God forgive me for not being able to remember her name...Julie??) that I drove all the way from San Diego for these delectable delights, she gave me the whole back story about the cookies, the bar and herself!  She made me glad I made the trek, rainboots and all, to try them for myself.  I paired the very moist cookies (they were the cake like version) with the pomegranate cider, and was in heaven.  

I've tried both versions of the cookie, the cake like version and the cookie version (The cake like is the traditional, the cookie version of the "cookie" is more Americanized, or so I've been told).  Almost all places fail in making the cake like version of the cookie because it seems like they use boxed cake mix, however, Pi really set the bar (no pun intended, okay, maybe a little :) for rainbow cookies.  The cake was moist, there was a generous amount of preserves and it was covered in chocolate ganache (No nestle chocolate chips here!)!! I didnt try the food as it was pretty late however my friend has promised to try them out and post a review.  If you're dying for rainbow cookies, go here! You'll be glad you did!
author: Dominique M.

description: I've lived in NYC, and I just had the best meatball sub I have ever had in my life in the Mission. Perfect bread. Mellow sauce. Well spiced. The salads were well dressed. And a great beer selection.
author: Matt S.

description:
Went to Pi Bar with some trepidation on weds after reading Yelp reviews. As any fan of beer will tell you, we are living in amazing times in terms of the number and breadth of quality brews available so I make it a point to check out new places with a strong beer menu. On that front, Pi does not disappoint. A perusal of their list and chats with Jen, one of the owners, confirms that they are serious about their beer and interested in customer feedback. Jen really knows her stuff. 

We got in just in the nick of time for the $6.28 daily 3-6 slice and beer of day option. Beer was Great White or something. Not bad, but I'm not a white beer guy. The Elysian ESB I had next and my friends Green Flash IPA were both superb and there were many other great choices. As someone else pointed out, not an overwhelming number which is good.

The pizza? First slice took awhile to appear and came out burnt on the bottom. We pointed this out to our friendly bartenders who promptly replaced with fresh slices from a new pie. Pizza was as close to New York style as I've had here, save maybe for Arnels. Pretty damn tasty. We ate every bite, crust and all. No issue with that as others have pointed out here. Crust was nice and crispy, not  too hard.  So tasty in fact that we order another slice, but this time with the homemade (on premises) sausage. Wow, even better! Not your typical pizza sausage but really tasty with lots of subtle flavors like fennel. I like the fact that they sell by the slice and it's $3.14 for cheese, .50/topping. $3.65 seems like a pretty good deal for a very good slice of pizza. Is it the best pizza I've ever had? Hardly but very tasty and far better than most of doughy, over cheesed stuff that passes for pizza in this town. 

Herein lies the problem with Pi IMHO. Is it a beer bar that serves pizza or a destination pizza place? From what I've read about the full pie prices, they are priced like a destination pizza place (aka Beretta, Gialino, Defina, Little Star, etc). Yet the description on the website and the results are more like they are aiming to be an everyday place.

There's a lot of expectations in this town around really good pizza so the bar is set pretty high. They should be cut some slack for being new (I mean, they've only been open a week) and be given a chance to work out the kinks in the food. My advice if you're unhappy is to let them know. They were very attentive and focused on getting things right. I'll definitely be going back cause I love what they're doing with the beer and the ability to get a decent slice or 2 on short notice but if I'm looking for a pizza night out I think there are some better choices.
author: John B.

description:
Unfortunate paint colour. Sort of dusty mauve. Very circa 1988. Tin ceiling must go.

Clean kitchen and you can see in! So you KNOW it's clean!

Food's ok.

Too many children.

Bar is made to be eaten on. Nice and wide. Can appreciate that.
author: Amelia F.

description: The pizza is just okay, and the prices are high.  They serve beer in smaller glasses when the alcohol content is higher even though every other pub is serving a whole pint for the same price.  I just wasn't impressed.
author: DSX M.

description: Pizza, great beer selection, math references, and not overwhelmingly hipster. Exactly what I want.
author: Jack K.

description: checked this place out on a Friday night with some friends, the place was packed as it was also SF beer week! Living in the Mission, we have been planning to visit Pi or sometime now, this place did not disappoint! great beer selection and pizza.the pizza crust is perfectly thin and crisp, not too doughy and you can add your own toppings. really loud in there but it all adds to the experience!  cheers to another great place in the Mission!
author: heather z.

description: Everytime I come here, I like it a little bit more.  The pizza gets tastier, the appetizers do too (breaded mozzarella sticks, spinach salad with sausage, oh my).  I love sitting at the bar with a glass of wine or a beer and a pizza.  I only come on weeknights so it's never been crowded when I come, which is maybe one of the reasons I like it more and more.
author: Melinda C.

description: As a born-and-raised New Yorker, I really appreciate a NY-style crust with a worthy red sauce here in SF. There's some great Chicago style pizza in this city, but "thin crust" does not mean NY-style in California. Chewy, with the perfect proportions of sauce to cheese, and in SF style, classed-up with toppings like balsamic onions. Outside of the classic red sauce and cheese option, their Death by Mushroom pie is heavenly - add garlic and balsamic onions! Aside from the pizza, the beer selection is great and the location and interior is chill. Great addition to lower valencia and the skirts of noe/mission!
author: Kabri L.

description: Happy hour is great ..... They change their beer offering monthly.  FEB is strong beer month. They had a beer on tap called  "Fifty-fifty Concentrated Evil" !!  Ohhh Baby! (lap, lap, Mmmmm) 10.8% of universe problem solving liquid. They offersome food, but it's mostly pizza. From what I hear it's wonderful.  Now it gets crowded on the weekend, so come early and stake you claim because there aren't a lot of places to sit, and it get's louder than a baby's Momma Jerry Springer episode. So drink up some delicious evil and move your as down V street.
author: Mark B.

description: I'm not a big beer person, so I feel like I am probably missing out on the best part of Pi Bar. The pizza is ok- I've given this place 3 chances and it hasn't really impressed. Haven't tried non-pizza food items, but if the pizza isn't awesome, not all that enticed to try other things.
author: Nicole A.

description: I just realized I haven't updated my review of Pi Bar. This place has grown on me. It's safe to say I love it. I guess I just had to figure out what my favorite pie is - it's the white pie with olives, mushrooms and sometimes garlic. Not for everyone I know, but I love it. Give me a pint or two of Blind Pig to go with it and I am a very happy camper. In fact, it's becoming a bit of an addiction and I can be found there just about every Thursday or Friday evening.
author: robin b.

description:
I am very picky about my pizza after working in North Beach for 12 years. I know a good slice when I taste one, and the Pi Bar makes a damn good pie! I went there last night with some friends and ordered a small pie to share and the fried mozzarella. We topped our pizza with portabella mushrooms, the Italian sausage, and onions. Oh my god it was so good my mouth is watering just thinking about it! My friend said that it was like gourmet pizza! I inquired about the ingredients and was happy to find out that they order the majority of their food from organic local sources! 
Also I am a big fan of ciders so I was thrilled when they had a great organic pomegranate cider, and I ordered a Belgian beer called Kasteel Rouge that was suggested to me, man was it good! It's sweet which I like and tasted like chocolate covered cherries. I would go back just for that beer! 
As for the service I have to say that they were on top of their game. It was packed when we walked in and despite the fact that we couldn't get a seat right away we were totally taken care of. The staff was friendly and attentive and the food came promptly. There is a really great vibe over all, it feels like the Pi Bar has been there for ages it's hard to believe they just opened. I used to work at the Dovre Club which is down the street from the Pi Bar and I have to say that it's a great addition to the neighborhood!
author: Tara O.

description: I'm doing an update because this place rocks.  Nice staff, yummy pizza, great beer. They are coming up on their one year anniversary, and they deserve your love and business.  They are the real deal.
author: Kari J.

description: The pizza is fine, the toppings list is short, the crust is delectable, the beer selection is short sweet and finely curated. The decor has kind of an identity crisis going on.... Half NOPA half biker bar that took over an English pub haphazard could describe it or it could be apathy. Not vegan friendly so leave the cheese-fearing at home.
author: Jared Z.

description:
I want to like this place, it's right by house and would like the idea of having a local place I can go to regularly, but they still have working out to do in my mind.

To me the pizza is okay, not great. Their on my block so I'm sure I'll be back, but I wouldn't drive to go get it. Enough people seem to have comments already on sauce to cheese ratios, I don't think I can add anything here.

I've ordered from there twice, the first time they said come back in 20 minutes, I did and it took 45. The second time the said 15 and it took 30 minutes. It doesn't take 45 minutes to make a pizza, but if it does,  at least have the decency to tell your customer so I don't have to stand there waiting for 25 minutes with nothing to do.

I also asked if I could do a half and half, with two different ingredients, the answer was no. I don't think I've ever been to a pizza place that said no to that request before. Given that there large is so big it's got to feed multiple people, I would hope they will work out a way to solve this problem.

Lastly the toppings list could be improved a little, maybe some specials, some seasonal options. More than one anchovy a slice!

I hope they figure this place out, I like the idea of being a regular, but right now it's only on occasion.
author: Daniel L.

description:
Went there on the "official" opening night (though it had actually opened a couple nights before. Party of 5 adults, one baby on a Thursday night. We got there just after 6 and waited a good 30-45 minutes before we got a (small) table. Downed a few beers while we waited, which made the wait go a lot faster. Definitely lots of energy in this place---a communal table that had patrons rotating through it on a regular basis, a lively bar, and loads of people eating, waiting, drinking. Mixed crowd, though less hipster-ish than Beretta just down the street. 

We ordered a pasta dish and the cesar salad to start. Meh. I'd stick with the pizzas. Both dishes were pretty small, and definitely too small to serve as share plates (we literally each had one bite of the pasta dish before it was gone). They were fine, but nothing special. We ordered a large pizza ($22) with three additional toppings: sausage (homemade---yum!), meatballs, and roasted peppers. One of our friends tried to add a fourth topping (holy toppings!), but was advised against it because the crust is too thin to withstand all the topping pressure. Or something like that. 
Anyway, the pizza came out piping hot. The sausage was good, but the meatballs were more flavorful. I chased it all down with a Coney Island Pilsner. Excellent. The large pizza meant we could all have one giant slice and half of another slice, with one half slice left. That was plenty for us, but if you're hungry, you might want to get a large and a small for a group of 5. Besides, who doesn't like leftover pizza?! 
In all, I'd say the pizza was pretty good, the vibe good, but really the best part is that it's within walking distance of our house. Can't beat that.
author: Bess K.

description: Pretty fair pizza, decent beer selection and ambiance, though bar staff has a bit of an attitude - but isn't that bartenders in general - as a former one, perhaps that is where it comes from... dishes out the beverages, controlling the alcohol consumption. Been back a second time and the pizza definitely improved from the last visit, got a whole pie with cheese, spinach, onions, and sausage - banging! ...
author: Gregory H.

description: Having moved to SF from NYC I was thrilled to hear there was going to be a Brooklyn style pizza joint opening up a block from my house. I could not have been more dissapointed by the pizza. The crust tastes like I imagine cardboard would taste and the toppings are equally tasteless and unispired (I had one slice of sausage and one slice of pepperoni and garlic). A slice is cheap to be sure, but then again, think of all the other things your four dollars could buy that actually have flavor.
author: B. C.

description:
I love the straight-forward philosophy of this place.  The space and kitchen is open and the food is unpretentious.  I don't want oysters and goat cheese on my pizza.  I want the real thing.  Finally, a pizza place that gets it right!  And it's not just any "pizza joint".  They have 12 taps of local craft brew and a very intelligent selection of Belgium beers as well.  And the bartender was an encyclopedia of beer knowledge.  Not to mention, very sweet in answering my many annoying questions about each beer, even though she was totally slammed with customers.  

And the fact that they make their own sausage and cure their own anchovies, makes me love Pi Bar even more.  Unpretentious, but not lacking for any quality.  The cheese, sauce and crust are one and the slice literally melts into your mouth.  It's a zen-ful experience.  

This is a great place just to hang out in.  It's relaxed, yet jovial.  I can't wait to come back.
author: Sappy B.

description: I was, as all transplanted New Yorker's are, sad to see the state of NY pizza here in SF. And when I heard that someone who actually understood our plight set out to rectify this and create Pi Bar, I was insanely excited (Not to mention that it's super close to my house). And when I went, I got a severely overpriced cardboard slice of pizza. It was entirely a disapointment. The crust was really hard and nearly impossible to eat towards the edge and the sauce and cheese were out of proportion both to each other and the crust. There wasn't that foldability that all NY slices have. The beers selection however, it what earned Pi Bar it's two stars. They was an impressive selection both on tap and bottled and all that we tried were delicious.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
This is a strange place. It's not what you would expect. If you're expecting a bar, it's not bad. I'd give it 4 stars, if it's a pizza place, only 2 stars. The pizzas are big and thin, but there's not much flavor to them. The crust is chewy and bready and very little in terms of toppings. The sauce is not that exciting. Sigh. The pizzas are pretty expensive for what you get. You can easily spend $30 on a fairly scarce pizza.  

On the plus side, the beer selection has been great. The place is always packed. Maybe it's beer fans who frequent the place. 

The atmosphere is fairly chaotic. It's more like a neighborhood bar that just happens to serve average pizzas. The servers are nice and work hard but there's not much organization about where to stand or who's next in line. 

Go here for beer and maybe a slice, but if you're expecting really good pizza in a restaurant type setting you probably want to go elsewhere. 
If you want tasty pizza, I recommend Little Star and Paxtis.
author: John W.

description:
the pizza is great!!!  It's warm and cozy with an incredible wine a beer list.  
I look forward to trying everything on the menu!  What a fantastic addition to the neighborhood!!
author: shannon m.

description: We've only ordered takeout and want to come back and eat in. They have awesome customer service and the staff are very friendly. Our pizza was fresh and you could tell made with love. I like that they use fresh local ingredients too and fresh parmesean cheese. Anyways I am glad they are in our neighborhood! Thanks Pi Bar!
author: Leeshawn N.

description: Yep.  Still great beers and good pizza.  Yep still great service and even better that its going the anti-yelp way.  Love it.  Hey easy to please.  I don't usually do a second review however this place is getting knocked about pretty hard when it shouldn't.  But do you really care what I think.  Get drinking you filthy slepps!.  Its thanksgiving!.  Go the mighty turduckin!
author: Nick T.

description: The pizza was good, but a bit salty. Probably because of the pepperoni?  Mozzarella sticks were tasty and not too greasy. It was a bit disheartening that we realized each mozzarella bite was over $1.50 when you calculated it out. So expensive!  The service was really chilly and non-attentive. I don't think I'd go back, even though the food was good.
author: Aly M.

description:
i'd been hearing this place pumped up for a while, and after reading about the dude from NY not being able to get good pizza in SF and wanting to recreate the pie from some NY strip mall of his past, i was intrigued.  

but this place is a swanky beer bar that happens to serve some mediocre pizza.  you would be hard pressed to find anything like this in NYC; flavorless crust a bit on the thicker side, bland sauce and not enough of it, salty cheese, small slice, and to boot it was completely burnt.  

want a soda?  they have two or three Thomas Kemper varieties for $4.  they do have a decent beer selection, but the pints are $5.

the interior of the place is nice, and they were blasting world/club music, i felt like i was paying more for the space than the offerings.  if you want to drink $5 beers in a swanky bar, come here.  if you want New York pizza, this place has nothing on Arinell's.
author: Daryl F.

description: I figured out the $6.28 price for the beer + cheese pizza slice. I felt smart for like two seconds. I personally wouldn't pair a pear cider (pun alert!) with a slice, but it wasn't bad. Decent pizza, just not exactly my favorite. Had a La Chouffe to chase the cider...
author: Maximillian M.

description: This place is the business.  Totally laid back atmosphere.  Great selection of beers that changes regularly.  Really good pizza.  Happy hour slice and a beer for $6.28.  They're pretty kid friendly too which is cool for me when the missus is at work...
author: Wes H.

description:
not sure the neighborhood needed another hip pizza spot but pi is close to home so i gave it a try.  

IMHO, this is a decent bar that happens to serve pizza.  good choice of microbrews, and full service at the bar, which is nice.  big issue: the pizza was utterly forgettable, which isn't a good thing when you're got little star and defina up the street.

if you want a better pie, try one of the above, or gialina, or berreta, or even pauline's.  if you want to hang out with hipsters and have a pint or two, head here.  i had decent expectations, and pi didn't even come close.
author: Matt G.

description: This is my friends favorite place, her lounge, home away from home. I like it. The beer selection is impressive and the food sophisticated.
author: Duncan M.

description: I give them 3.5. This place is in the middle of no where close by my friend's place so I've been here two times. Bother times I came out satisfied. They have a great selection of beer and cider. The small pizza is pretty big, ceasar salad was very tasty this time had the cheese and anchovies which they lacked last time. Spinach sausage salad is ok, I can do without. I had a mushroom olive meatball pie and a garlic sausage onion one. The meatball was my favorite out of the two tasty meatballs, mushrooms are not button mushrooms they taste like the fancy ones from the farmers market, very fresh and good. They also don't use black olives it was also some fancy olives. The crust was nice and thin but crunchy and not soggy. This place is good if you are in the area go for it!
author: Karen T.

description: Great little place over in the Mission District. They rotate their tap beer selection, so you can go often and try new things. In addition to the taps they have plenty of bottled Belgian beers to keep you going. Pizza by the slice with an interesting selection of toppings was also nice, though wasn't a complete fan of it, but I was there for the beer.
author: Reuben B.

description:
although i did enjoy the thin crust, the pizza was mediocre. for $4.25 i got two toppings on an average sized slice. i thought they were skimp on the toppings, and the sauce was nothing to write home about. though i have not tried their pastas, salads, or appetizers. 

they do have a large variety of beer (import and domestic) with the selections written on a large chalkboard, a beautiful long wooden bar, a communal table and a handful of other tables to sit at. the staff are very friendly, and the restaurant has a nice brown interior making it a warm ambiance.
author: Sheri N.

description:
I am honestly confused by some people's perceptions of the pizza here. Order a pie here, especially with the Death by Mushroom sauce, and you will be eating some of the best thin-crust pizza in San Francisco. 

I will admit, the way they do the slices is kind of weak, so maybe that's skewing results? But slices at a pizza place are not usually consistent anywhere. Come with a friend and get the whole pie.

Other than that, the beer selection is excellent, staff is friendly, the vibe is great, and they play really good music. 

One funny note: if you come here around 6pm on a Friday night, you will find the entire place crawling with young parents and their offspring letting off steam after a long week. They clear out pretty quick, though!
author: Mattie P.

description: Drinks are a good deal. I haven't tried the pizza, but I really like the location.
author: Mei F.

description:
Fantastic pub.
The beer selection is astounding and revolves with the seasons. Had the garlic bread and the "beignets" with bacon to start, then the large mushroom sauce pizza with meatballs (truly handmade and delicious) and onion. The large fed 5 of us comfortably. The service was attentive and friendly. 

The only 'needs improvement' would be their website.

We almost did not go because the Yelp reviews were lackluster. Must say we had a wonderful experience.
author: Joe B.

description: Came here for dinner with some friends to check it out. Restaurant had a great laid-back bar feel which luckily wasn't too crowded that night. Tables are pretty small and limited, so not sure how easy it would be to snag a table on a busier night. Was a little disappointed in the menu selection. Not too many appetizers to choose from and all the pizzas are DIY where you pick your own toppings. Started with polenta fries, which came in a smaller portion than I imagined it to be. Ordered a large pizza, which ended up being huge! Overall, prices are not too bad for the size of the pizza, but I've had better. However, I see all the Yelp reviews here raving about the beer, so I might have to come back here one day to grab a drink.
author: Vivian D.

description: Very disappointing. Service very slow and with someone in an unclean outfit.
